name: Game Dev Tycoon
description: In Game Dev Tycoon you replay the history of the gaming industry by starting your own video game development company in the 80s. Create best selling games. Research new technologies and invent new game types. Become the leader of the market and gain worldwide fans.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows XP SP3 Processor: 2 GHz dual core Memory: 2 GB RAM Graphics: Hardware Accelerated Graphics with dedicated memory Additional Notes: minimum resolution of 1024x768
recommended_requirements: OS: Windows 7/8 Memory: 4 GB RAM Graphics: Hardware Accelerated Graphics with 1GB memory

Game Dev Tycoon  is a cute and witty take on the video game development process. There is a certain level of addiction the game instills in the player, pushing you to continue to develop new titles or create new businesses to try and squeeze out the best review scores ensuring a steady stream of sales which equates to more cash for your little simulated development company.   The pacing works well and gives you roughly 6-8 hours of play time for the 30 years you get to play. Once you reach the end the game does allow you to keep going, but no more story elements unfold (nothing beyond the PS4 and next Xbox).  If you can find Game Dev Tycoon on sale on Steam it’s certainly worth picking up.   THE GOOD  - Addictive gameplay - Solid design - It is easy to understand - Fun real life gaming representations - You can interact with the community   THE BAD  - Can be very easy - Flat gameplay  DISASTER | BAD | MEDIOCRE | OKAY |   GOOD   | GREAT | AMAZING | MASTERPIECE

Developing your company from a garage developer to a well known indie developer is really fun, and enough for me to recommend this game, however:  1. The replayability is not great, each game is pretty similar 2. The modding community is a bit scarce 3. The system for rating games is bad. Because you compete against youself, if you make a really good game, all your games after that will get bad ratings unless they are better than your really good game. This is the worst thing about the game because it discourages you from making good games and encourages you to make games that are just a little bit better than your last, whcih isn't fun.  If the devs make a sequel and take the community's advice on board it could be a masterpiece because this is a great concept.  7/10

A game that is a lot more fun than it looks, is very easy to play but maybe not so easy to put down again. A trip down memory lane to the technology limitations of the day back in the 1980s, right through to (beyond) today's generation of fabulous game engines and technologies. Where you invest your research and development efforts will determine your success. A great title!

Gave Dev Tycoon lets you start your own company as a game developer. At first you start small in your garage, but as you make more and more successful games you can change offices, hire staff, and upgrade your skills through training.   While it is a simple concept, game dev tycoon is promising, in the sense that it keeps adding variety to your game making process and letting you make more complex choices as you progress through the game. The graphics and music are quite simple and not really an asset to be discussed for this game. Its gameplay largely consists of you adjusting sliders so as to decide which concepts you are going to give emphasis on while creating each game, such as sound, graphics etc. You also witness the emergence and disappearance of several types of consoles and decide where to release each game, while also keeping in mind the market trends.   The most prominent problem with this game, would be that you get to decide based on trial and error more often than not, and the feedback you get about the choices you made is not entirely helpful for you to choose better next time around. The existance of a wiki for this game has made it so that tons of people end up following just that, since it is way less frustrating to progress in this way. Overall, I wouldnt call game dev tycoon a bad game, but a game that could use some polishing to shine.  + great genre/topic/platform variety + easy to grasp, hard to master   - game choice feedback is vague

As an Indie game, this is not bad.   I'm a fan of the original Tycoon games, so it's safe for me to say that this Indie game made it pretty far. If you think about it, it's not about the graphics or music - it's about the strategy and the satisfaction you get from that successful achievement of being, well, successful. This is one feeling we all have deep down inside and it can come from anywhere, real life scenarios, or video games.   Rather you're fishing and finally got a hook, or moving to the next stage in this game it's the same feeling of accomplishment. The only thing the game lacks is maybe a higher time frame between console releases. It seems to be a little too fast-paced when you're actually sitting here playing it. This game could also use a meter on how fast you'd like time to pass rather it's real-time or 100x faster for example.  Pros: -Addictive gameplay -Allows your creativity to fly -Good engine -Basic controls (Rather you're a gaming veteran or a newcomer, anyone can play with ease)  Cons: -No control on the time flow  -You'll mostly always feel rushed -Could use some more tweaking  Overall, I'd give this a 8/10. I can tell this took some time to actually develop - as I said before it's not about the graphics or music that made this the game it is today, it's the gameplay. From what I can tell, it took awhile to actually make this game fully functional which needs to be credited. This could be a text-based game and I'd still enjoy it.  Would I recommend it? Maybe, I wouldn't say $10 USD would be worth Game Dev Tycoon, however I'd say around the $4.99 or lower range (on sale) would be reasonable. Some have regrets about buying this game, you need to give it time or maybe start over. The point is, have fun.

Pick the perfect combination of concept, genre, and platform (while managing marketing, budget, and personnel), and you could have the next gaming sensation on your hands.  Game Dev Tycoon is a fun business sim with plenty of inside jokes for anyone who follows the gaming industry. Graphics and sound are quirky (in a good way), the interface in unintrusive and functions rather smoothly, and gameplay is entertaining. My major criticism would be a lack of replay value; after you've successfully completed a 35-year 'career,' I'm not sure there's much reason to return for a second pass at the game.  Nevertheless, that first trip through the game consumes a solid five or six hours of gameplay -- during which I never found myself bored. Overall, Game Dev Tycoon is well worth the price of admission, especially if you can pick it up on sale.

Game Dev tycoon is one of the only games in recent times that has had mee hooked for hours straight, causing me to go without brishing my teeth or getting changed in favour of playing this gem of an indie title rather than catch the bus to the job that I don't have.  This game is addictive as f**k. Starting from a guy in a shed in the early 1980s and watching the company of your own name (in my case, NotEACorp) growing into a company releasing games about ninja princesses and getting punched in the balls by critics is wholly satisfying, except for when a critic pans your game, which only makes you want to make a better game to impress him/her/it, thus contributing to the addiction.  My only complaint about this game is that, for a game made up of a load of 2D sprites, the randomly appearing framerate drops, while suprising, are more annoying than anything. I understand that indie games aren't the best optimised games on the market, but this is giving me horrifying nighmares about GTA 4 all over again.  VERDICT: Go do everything you need to do in your life, gather a stash of food, then buy this game. You'll be glued to your PC until an inevitable powercut comes along to say Hi.  10/10. It's not perfect. There's no such thing as a perfect game. But this is as close to perfect as games really come these days.

One of those games where you don't expect much and then it surprises you. Yes, the core gameplay mechanics may be around sliders and yes, at late stages when you have R&D/hardware lab researching something it may lag here and there even on high-end PC-s but put a little imagination in it and it will entertain you more than 90% of today's AAA-s.  To re-create some of the most memorable titles is really priceless, there are easter eggs and some amazing feelings of satisfaction as you get successful. Also, I would recommend some mods for expanding the game even further. At the price, it's not spending. It's investing into some nostalgic gaming moments. Just plain and simple fun.  86/100

I've been playing this game for only a day, and I already want to have its babies. It's the first game in two months that made me stay up late so I could keep playing it. The mechanics are simple and easy to understand, allowing you to get right to the important business of building and customizing your games. And when you finally get that first 10 rating, and that first million bucks, everything has been worth it. Greatly looking forward to sequels/updates/mods/finishing the game.  -----  This is five weeks and 40 hours of additional gameplay after that first paragraph. I still recommend this game, but with a lot less enthusiasm. The game gets very repetitive after a while, especially because financial success hinges on putting out one near-perfect game every few years or so, with everything else just being filler. I absolutely hope there's a bigger badder sequel in a year or two, one that addresses the following issues:  Idiot Publishers: Your mid-game is overly dependent on using publishers so you can make larger games for more money and fans. But more often than not the publisher will either ask for a game you haven't researched, a format you don't have rights to, or a terrible topic/genre combo. I get that it's supposed to make you take chances and expand your options, but if I'm desperate and need a medium game fast, I'd like to actually be able to make one. Employee Stagnation: In order for their skills to improve, your employees must train. Making games gives them nothing; you MUST spend time and research points and capitol on boosting their skills. And you have to do this a lot, which means that you can't be constantly working on games - or researching new topics/engine elements. Chronic Indie Mindset: Even once you hit the late game and become an industry juggernaut, it's still just seven dudes cranking out a game. Yes, you can eventually develop a hardware lab and an R&D department, but they don't directly assist in game-making. I want to become a monster, with dozens - or even hundreds - of employees, making multiple games at once, training some people while others are dedicated to improving my engine and so on. Research Bottleneck: As mentioned above, you need research points to train employees as well as to research new topics and game engine elements. The only way to generate RP for most of the game is to make more games, a newer engine, or generate a game report. As such, you often end up falling behind in either training or engine (or god forbid, both) as you struggle to devote enough points to their multiple needs. I'd recommend being able to create an R&D lab much sooner, thus giving the player many more points to work with, rather than reducing point requirements. Hardware Focused: When I first started playing, I really loved how the game told the history of gaming consoles, as it's not something you hear about a lot when researching gaming history. But consoles are almost exclusively the only outside influence on your game-making. Nothing about software or legal battles or any of that. Just console development. And while interesting, it's such a small part of the story. Forced Conformity: One of this game's mechanics has you matching game topics to genres; the better the match, the better it sells. In other words, you can't make a unique game. For example, according to GDT, Prison/RPG is an okay combination. But what if I want to make a stellar Prison/RPG? Instead of just stating that such-and-such a combination is good or bad, it should be up to the player to make it good or bad. Also, the entire nation of Japan would like to say something about Romance/RPG not being a great combination; I have 60 hours of gameplay and that still messes me up.  And yet despite all those flaws, it's still an enjoyable game. In my last playthrough I jokingly made a Vampire RPG called Count of Calypso and it got me out of the basement. The three sequels got me into the final game stage, paid for my R&D lab and new game engine, and became the game I was known for, respectively. I created the Fallout franchise with the help of Dave Johnson, head of Departure Science. Tom Schoffer is somehow a tech genius and became my first AI specialist. I made Half-Life, Half-Life 2, and won the game before I could releas Half-Life 3. There are so many good stories that come out of Game Dev Tycoon; I just wish it were less frustrating to create them.

I really want you to know more about this game, this game is just great. Imagine that you create your company's video games and create your best seller, the games that are sold several million copies.  ➊ You create your own business. ➋ You create your own graphics for your games. ➌ You hire employees. ➍ You can do training to improve your skills and your employees. ➎ You face the successes and disappointments out of the creations of games.  It is a very good game to understand the difficulty of the editor and and understanding to create a game in some ways.

The story of the game is that you go back to the year 1985 and start your own game company. You start off in a garage which you can upgrade to a technical suite and more! As time progresses there are news popups which describe events that are taking place in the gaming industry at the time. For example: Vonny has just released their second video game system. Some games you make may be a smash hit but others not so great, you must be wise with the topic, genre and console. You can earn millions or become bankrupt. To improve the chance of making a great game is to hire staff which becomes available in the upgraded garage (becomes the technical suite). The staff can be used to help make games, research topics and research different features of the engine.   When you start off, the game may be a bit tricky but once you learn which topic matches with which genre it will seem easier. With the ability to make games there is a cost. At the start of each career you recieve a certain budget which you can use to develop your first game! It randomly selects the first topics you can use so don't excpect to get the one you want. During making games with the budget you can go bankrupt, although it seems bad you can get two chances before you finally go bankrupt and have to start over.  Overall Rating: 9/10 (Highly Recommended)  I rate this game a 9 out of 10 because of how addicting it is, the details of the game and the dream of any gamer to make their own game company. Green Heart Games need to make a few tweaks which are only little ones. For example when the reviews of the games you make pop up it takes 20 seconds to display all of them. I feel that this wastes time but you can download a mod off of the workshop to reduce it to 1 second but hopefully they will change it anyway :).  Thanks for reading this review and good luck with your game company :)  Daniel

Game Dev Tycoon is a strategy game developed by Greenheart games. You begin the game by naming your character with limited customization and naming your company, then with a very helpful tutorial system, you're off to create games as you see fit.  When you start, the only thing you can do is create a game, you can make it text based or 2-D gameplay, but as you progress through the years you will be able to research new things such as the ability to make a 3-D engine, better A.I., environmental effects, all that stuff. To get these research ideas, you must get research points by making a game, engine, or doing something like creating a report on what you did wrong when developing your game.   When you begin making your game, you can choose the genre, which topic it will be based on (Ancient history, ninjas, spies) and choosing which systems it will be on You can also create your own engine with many of these research skills, which can cost quite a lot sum of dosh. When developing your game, you have to use 3 sliders to see how much time you want to spend on a part of a game, for example, do you focus on the story more than the game or vice versa? Graphics or sound, A.I. or Dialogue? As you develop your game, Journalists will ask for interviews and ask on you're opinion on things such as what's important in a genre of a game, you can also hype up the game by saying stuff like '*Name* will be one of the greatest', you can also sign missions such as a plan to get women into gaming which will cost you, but earn you a lot of fans and respect. Once you've created your game, you will gain experience in pretty much all your skills such as your story writing, gameplay designing, sound and graphics, etc. The game will also then be reviewed by 4 reviewers, you may start by getting 5s, 4s, and probably 2s, but once you've managed to get your first 10 out of 10, you will want to raise your hand in success.  If you've done badly, you can generate a game report which can give you advise, such as the Commodore 64 has a large adventure fanbase, or the PC community has a large strategy fanbase, and whether things such as dialogue is important for certain genres. However, if you still manage to do badly, you will enter bankrupcy and will have to take a loan from the bank, fail that, game over.  As you earn more money, you can move into bigger offices where you can recruit more staff members as well as make the place look very pretty. As you make good games you will gain fans, who will definatly buy your games and if you got 100K of them, you'll be able to self publish your games, you can also sign publish contracts with companies such as úbersoft or Electronic Mass Productions to gain notice in the industry, but they'll call the shots on what you make. Later in the game you can also build your custom console to release onto the market. I gotta say, the gameplay is pretty damn addicting, so much so I've been spending 6 hours into a single play session which I never really do a lot, and that says something for me.  Nothing to say in the visual department, it looks clean and reminds me of a few flash games.  The sound is pretty good too, nice beeps and bloops and the music keeps a smile on my face 99% of the time.  As far as complaints go.....well, there isn't any on the top of my head to be honest, I was too occupied in making games and having too much fun to notice any.  Overall, Game Dev Tycoon is a brilliant game and you should absolutly purchase it as soon as you can.  I'd play it for decades.  9/10

This is the first game of this type that I've played. If you are excited by the idea of owning your own game developing business, this game will hold intrinsic delight for you. That was the case with me, so natuarally I liked this game.  Especially at first, it's fun creating the games. Basically, after you decide to make a video game, you allot portions of time to specific development aspects like graphics, sound, world design, etc. You do so by sliding a meter up or down depending on how much time you want to spend on that aspect of design. You must use wisdom, because certain game genres and topics will turn out better or worse depending on how much time you spend on a certain aspect of design. At first the gameplay was exciting for me. It's enjoyable to see the monetary effects of your good game design ;) . But for the most part, you as the player as repeating the same processes for designing each game. It's not a thoughtless procedure (because you have to figure out what to spend time on in development, pick a topic, etc) but you're pretty much following the same game mechanic(s) over and over to make each game.  As times goes on, you can market your game, research new topics, train and hire employees, put up a booth at the National game convention, take publishing deals, etc. Though these are varying ideas, you pretty much get the same 'feel' when you're playing. It's point and click stuff, which is normal for a tycoon like this I suppose. For me personally, the game began to bore me a couple of hours into the gameplay, but I allowed myself to enjoy it and had fun making profit. What will keep you coming back is the steady introduction of new consoles and features. Just when you think you've seen all the game features, a new one may come up, like being able to use a Research and Development team to undergo projects.  The bottom line is that the feel of the game mechanics feels somewhat repititive and will likely bore you UNLESS you like the idea of being a big-time game dev. If that's you, then that idea which stands behind this game--and the desire to succeed--will be an incentive to play for some time. It wasn't an entirely enthralling experience, but I liked it.

His game is a wonderful nostalgia trip, with some minor flaws.  The graphic is nice and a little reto the music gets a bit annoying after a while.  Gamplay is solid, with some minor issues. The game roughly separates in three phases: Garage, small time developer and AAA-Studio.  The first phase is easy and was my personal favourite: You just make games you like and combine new ideas, without any boring micro management.  The second phase steps up the difficulty a notch: You move into a studio and hire staff to make even bigger games. Suddendly you have to maage much more stuff and cash becomes a serious issue. Do you burn money on a new game-engine or concentrate on churning out games.  The third and final stage is a bit easier in my opinion: You hire more guys and concentrate on AAA-Titels, enlarge your studio and develop stuff like steam, you own consol and convention and so on...  My complaints are that after the time seems to 'fly by' at phase 2 and 3. Consols come and go and you almost have no chance to develop anything for them so you stay at one system you know well (the PC) and stick with it.  You have to train your avatar and staff using reseach points, which are not to easy to get in abundance. When you have enough research points and a trained staff at the final phase the game is almost over.  Some of the user interface is also no designed perfectly, but that may be my personal taste.  All in all a fun little experience with potential.

preface: In this review, keep in mind that I am following release dates to the US-only releases of products. I am not going to include EU or JP release dates due to this games setting being in the US. With that out of the way, let's get on with the review. - Game Dev Tycoon is a indipendence medium-game developed by Greenheart Games. And let me tell you: It's fun and addictive.  Game Dev Tycoon is about ''You'' being a video/PC-Game devloper in the post-1983 crash/Atari Shock and working your way up top all the way up to the year ...2018? I think. - [Let's talk about the story] The story isn't mush to talk about.  It begins with the post-'83 crash were computer-games survived the disaster, Nintendo reviving consoles in late-1985, Sega releasing GENESIS in 1989, SONY releases PS1 in late-1995 and so on.  The story is abridged though, so some events have been cut-out... such as Apple in the 80/90s, Linux, SEGA Saturn, all the add-ons for the GENESIS and *Panasonics 3DO  *Though the 3DO didn't do well in US and EU and is nothing in comparison to GENESIS and SNES, it deserves recognition in gaming history for selling well in Japan. - [Let's talk about the gameplay] When developing a game, you are presented with three development stages and three pillars for each development stage(total of nine pillars).  You adjust the pillars to what works and what doesn't work. Whether you want to focus a lot on gameplay or focus a little on A.I. or don't focus on the story etc.  After all the three development stages are done, you then wait for reviews.  If you get very bad reviews, then that's going to give you negative fans and make less money depending on the reviews and if you hyped the game before release.  If you get great reviews, then you are going to make a lot of money and have a huge following. journalists and critics will mention your great feat and with recognition you will get offers from different people.  Game dev Tycoon has a... sort of.. roguelike feel to it. If you mess up in the beginning and make a wrong decision then you could get a game-over.  If you make 1M dollars, you then move to an office and hire more staff and make bigger games.  Though I think this is a great gameplay mechanic, I still think there are a couple of ''missed opportunities'' in the gameplay that could have been in the game. Such as:  -You can't make a launch title. Or/and getting an offer from SONY or Nintendo for an exclusive title. -You can't put a price on a game.  -Why can't you make something viral? like spreading a rumour of a hidden room or a mythical creature or something, like GTA with big foot. Or Mortal Kombat with the blood code on SNES. -Why can't you make 2 games at the same time. one small game an a large game for example. -Why can't you make an expansion pack on a normal game? You can make an Exp. pack, but only on MMOs. -Why can't my character have a background? not all companies starter out as one guy like Bungie. Some starter out as three guys such as Blizzard. ...and so on. I have a mush bigger list in my head of ''missed opportunities'' with GDT. These are a few example. - [Let's talk about the Graphics] Game Dev Tycoons graphics is hand drawn animation. I like Game Dev. Tycoons graphics. - [Let's talk about the music] For a simulator that's all about developing games, the music in this game isn't really that important. Game Dev Tycoons music is relaxing and kind to your ears. - [Before I give my ''Final Score'', I would like to say something] GDT opened up my point of view of how it looks like when developing a game. Before I played GDT I thought ''Ok... developers keep saying in interviews that the reason they can't make a sequel is because it's NOT that easy'' and I am all like ''well... maybe they're just saying that because they just want to make money and don't really care about the fans''. And after I played GDT, I finally understood what developers were saying about ''It's NOT that easy''. - [Final Score] GDT is a great game... but I feel like there were a lot of missed oppertunities. But it can be forgiven because of the addicive gameplay and for being an indie-game. I didn't like that the story was abridged and your main-character was ''another avarage Joe''. That's why I give GDT a ''great'' 8.5/10 and a ''recommended'' for anybody.  I can reccommend game dev. Tycoon to anybody, even casuals. Even If you're not familiar with Simulations. And also, if you have the motivation to learn and such, then GDT is for you.  [Here is an idea I have for ''Greenheart Games'' if they ever make a sequel] If Greenheart Games ever make a sequel to GDT or an Exp. Pack. Then I am would like them to add those ''missed opportunities'' that I talked about in the ''gameplay''-section.  I would also like the sequel/exp. pack to follow the gaming history more accurately. - ...And that's my review of GDT. Peace out and have a good one.

Game Dev Tycoon is a simple game that is far from perfect but is a good way to spend a few hours. You can develop games for consoles from the early 80's to the future which is pretty sweet.  It is hard to master getting perfect ratings for your games as you will have to learn what type games work best on which console, which audience is best, and the best balance between graphics, sound and gameplay.  After the games 35 year end point you can continue playing, unlocking things and perfecting your games but after that it gets boring after 40-50yrs depending on how well you're doing.  It took me roughly 3 days to level up my character and employees to level 10, unlock everything and get all the achievements. It was fun and enjoyable but after the 20 hour mark it did get a bit boring and repetitive but the game is moddable and people have expanded upon and improved the game which is great for another couple of hours.  Is it worth buying? that depends... if you want a simple sim to keep you entertained for a weekend then yes. if you want something that will give you months of enjoyment you're probably best trying another game.

This is a fun little 'Tycoon' business sim game, its very casual and simple, but its nice enough if you get it on sale.  There are a few cons to go over:  The 'Same Type of Game' penalty should not apply, if you are doing it on a different platform, or there should be a similar (earlier) research to prequels called 'porting' where you are not allowed to change things in the dev process, but can spend the money to create the game again for a new platform.  Reviews need more feedback, only sometimes will a magazine article pop up telling you why the game flopped. When you make a game and focus the work in the correct areas, nail the target demographic and genre combinations, and do everything right and it still completely bombs, it would be nice to know what factors are affecting that. (Obsolete engine tech? Random chance? What?) as 'game reports' only give info on the things you already knew were correct. The info displayed in those magazine articles, should be in the reviews.  This concept however needs to be taken further.  Exclusivity Contracts: Theres needs to be more risk involved in the success of consoles, like having a manufacturer pay you a ton of money, but limiting you to their consoles for a duration of time.  Random Mode: A mode where the success of different platforms is randomized, and doesnt follow historic numbers. This would make the Exclusivity contracts more risky, as suddenly your Playstation contract screws you over, when the Philips CD-I dominates the market.  More consoles: CD-I, Neo Geo Arcade Cabinets, Jaguar, Ouya, Virtual Boy, Gameboy Color, GBA, etc. lets get them all in here.

Definitely a fun and addictive game, but needs more content. You start in the 1980's making games in your garage, and as you sell more games you can expand your company. Ultimately, while you are given many genres/topics/platforms to use to make your games, Game Dev Tycoon always follows the same path of progression. Once you figure out how to consistently release high scoring games you will be able to make money consistently and gain lots of fans. Since most of the gaming devices are inspired by real world events, if you know anything about gaming history its not hard to figure out the 'right' choices. There are some random events to change things up, but I find they are few and far between. It would be nice if the market would be more dynamic rather than follow static events, kind of like being able to play 'what if?' in gaming history. i.e. What if the Dreamcast had a major title that drove up console sales? Would that cause Microsoft to stay out of the market instead of trying to challenge Sony? What if the game with the most hype was really bad and led to less sales for the PS2? You do get to enter the console market with your own device, but this is so late into the game that it doesn't really mean much. Other suggestions, it would be nice if there was more to the game when it comes to sales and profit. Whether you self publish, or work with a publisher the amount of money you make seems to be only determined by the review score. You can take advantage of randomly generated trends in the market to boost sales, but if you make a good game it sells well regardless. It would be interesting to have random events in the market that can negatively affect the sales of high scoring games. Finally, the managing of employees could be more interesting. Maybe have them leave to form new studios, demand a raise, retire, happiness rating, etc. This would provide nice challenges to managing your studio besides training/replacing/send on vacation. Overall, I enjoy this game very much, but would like to see more depth to the gameplay to make the game more dynamic.

Cute little game, with one big, glaring flaw.  The gist of the gameplay is this: You have a game studio (initially in your garage) after having time-traveled back to the dawn of videogames(Apparently via Delorean). Your task is to make games, selecting genre, topic, platform, and later on audience and different game features to include. Each time you make a game, it gets a review score and is then put on sale for a period of time (no re-issues or long term issues, you get that one period and then never make a dime off that game again.)  During development, you choose different areas to allocate dev time to, like gameplay, world design, story, and artifical intelligence. Different genres emphasize different areas, and if you don't allocate your time accordingly the game quality suffers. The quality itself is measured in two areas: Design and Technology. As you develop the game, your developers add design and technology points to the game. The game tracks your record score in each area and tells you if you've beat it.  The values you need to use for each slider for each genre you can learn and save for future playthroughs, as well as which age groups prefer which topics, which topics work well with each genre and which don't, which genres work on which platforms, and which age groups use which platforms.  The flaw comes in with the bits you CAN'T learn from the game itself (In fact, people have had to source-dive to find bits of it), and how those bits are used.  Each genre has a Target Technology:Design ratio, the existence of which is hinted at nowhere in the game, which you get penalized for badly missing and a bonus for hitting come review time. Additionally, the generation of points for each is determined by a mix of your developers' stats and what area is being worked on, which makes sense, but again isn't indicated. Furthermore, the types of points produced by different focus areas needed for a particular genre don't always match up with the Tech:Design ratio that genre needs.  Strategy Games are probably the worst example of this, with a target ratio is 1.4 (7 points of Tech for every 5 points of design.) The three major Focus areas for a Strategy game are Gameplay (Produces 80% Design, 20% tech), Level Design (40% Design, 60% Tech), and World Design (60% Design, 40% Tech), with minor focus areas in Engine (20% Design 80% tech), AI (20% Design, 80% Tech), and Sound (60% Design, 40% Tech).  Which means that if you allocate time going off the focus areas with a balanced Dev Team, you'll end up slightly Design heavy, rather than fairly tech heavy as you're supposed to. And if you don't allocate based on the focus areas, you get penalized for that too.  So in order to make a really good strategy game, you need to be able to unbalance the points via other methods to make it favor tech despite the slight design emphasis built in to it. There's no indication anywhere of the game of any of that, except for the mediocre reviews you get despite having set new records for quality.  The other thing which isn't indicated is that the reviews set a target for your games based on your best previous games. It's realistic and not surprising, but also not indicated at all.  The combined effect is that to consistentently do well you have to do things that are unintuitive and that the game doesn't point you towards. If you try to generalize and swap back and forth between tech and design games, you'll end up only beating your record on one score at a time. And get penalized for it. Plus for not hitting the ratios. So you need to deliberately unbalance your dev team to favor either tech or design, and then stick with the genres that require whichever you're focusing on.   Thankfully, you can find out which those are from the wiki, as a result of helpful people source-diving, because it's sure not available in game.  Overall it's cute, silly, and fun, but the lack of indication of these very important mechanics can make it a bit frustrating (at least until you hit the wiki.)

Game Dev Tycoon is a fun and even nostalgic game for mature gamers out there. Players are tasked with starting a game development company and controlling the development and release of games as the years pass. New technology is introduced as time passes, which can play a role in how you wish to develop your games and company. The game is scripted to have release events of real consoles (named slightly differently for copyright reasons I am guessing). The release of these consoles is actually quite comical- you'd just have to play to see what I mean.  Games can be named, sequels can be made to games. Research can be done to unlock tech, employees can be selected and hired and trained and their roles can be specialized so that areas such as 'World Design' or 'Artificial Intelligence' can be professionally implemented in your games. You can control which employee works on which part of the game and how much time they have to spend.. different types of games will favor you spending more time in different areas. For example, RPG games will require you to allot more time in World Design and Story/Quests.   Overall, the design mechanics are a bit repetitive, but if you wish to have a lot of variety you can choose to develop different kinds of games. I was continually pleasantly surprised at how much detail was in the game and how much you could actually control and do. You can eventually create your own console, MMO's and even expansion packs.   The economy of the game is forgiving enough for new players, but in order to succeed to a high degree you would need to think carefully about what you are doing.  The first night I played, I played almost all night and managed to basically finish the main story line. That being said, I felt like there was a choice of pathways. I could go back to this game and not feel as though it was the exact same experience. Is there unlimited replayability? The short answer is no, but if you have a good imaginination, you could have fun almost every time you decide to play.

Game Dev Tycoon. A simple, yet great game. Let me get started. Firstly, this game is amazing because: You can mae your own games, your own consoles, complete contracts, work with publishers, make genre/topic combinations, and more. You can also make a Military/Action game, call it Call of Duty with medium graphics and give it to young audiences. Oh well, enough with trash-talking let's go to the real pros/cons PROS; -Music, It's random and suits the game. Calm. 9.5/10 -Graphics. They're not super next gen graphics, but simple that don't demand beefy computers. 9.5/10 -Art: Console art, or anything here, that's one of the best in the game. 10/10 -Story: Every console has been renamed, for example, Playstation is now Playsystem. The story is well fitting, amazing, and it can reach up to Playsystem 5, and Mbox Next, which have amazing Art. 10/10 -Mods: The community is making some amazing mods, to simple topic or researches mods, to mods that overhaul the game. I can say, this feature is really good, since it won't make you be bored of that game. The game Runs in JavaScript and CSS. I'm a modder myself as well. The new update will introduce workshop Support, which is making this feature much more amazing. There's even a MultiplayerMod. 10/10  CONS; - Playtime is around 6-8 hours in 30 years, and 10-12 in 42 years, the game ends too quick. - There won't be any more content updates, because the developers left that feature to modders.  Conclusion: I don't think that the Cons here win. I find the Pros really good so that's why I bought this game. I'm often in the forums, which are almost dead, but we hope after the 1.5.0 update, people may come over to the forums. There are quite good impressive mods in the forums if you want to check them out. Just Google greenheartgames forums.

This game is extremely similar to Kairosoft's  Game Dev Story  for mobile. Not sure which one came out first so I'm not implying anything just that if you enjoy Kairosoft's GDS this is an absolute grab. If you've never played GDS read on.  This is a game in which you start off as a programmer in your basement trying to put out a few games for the PC. Starting off you have a very limited selection of genres you can make and platforms you can put games out on. Over time you'll be able to expand your knowledge-base of genres and be able to put out games on multiple platforms. As you progress throughout the game you will also find yourself moving out of your basement and into proper offices and bring in NPCs to help you and feel like an actual company. You can research new genres, purchase contracts with new gaming systems, perform contract work on the side and even design your own console late in the game. You can train your employees and yourself to put a little more stats in those weak areas and pump out better games.   This game has a lot of possibilities and the replayability is seemingly endless with your playthrough being dependent on the sales of your games which is not the same each time through. I love the fact that the game pays homage to all of the consoles that have been on the market with such names as TES, Gameling, Playsystem, Dreamvast, Mbox, and more. This game is still fun even when you put out failures that don't sell.    Highly recommended

I spent 4 hours playing this game after I first bought it. Such a simple design yet SOOOOOOOOO addicting. After you make your first few 8-10 rating games you are hooked and want to see how far you can take your company. You might go bankrupt early on the first few times you play it but that might due to the random topic progression that can leave you high and dry at the start if you get oddball ones such as 'Evolution' or 'Life'. But just sart over and try again, the starting topics are random and you can choose to carry over the knowledge you leanred about each topic and genre from previous trys. Build your games off of what you know of trendy video games and you'll make the money you need to start playing around and getting creative with your game designs and taking chances. Messing up when you're working out of your garage by yourself but once you get into your second and third design studio making a bad game or two won't leave you in the red. None of this will really make sense until you play the game though lol. So take that as my review, i'm telling you things in the games terms expecting you to go buy and play the game then come back and nod and smile in agreement lol. This game is worth the $10 all day to me, but I got it on sale for $5. If you're more into action and graphics you will be very disappointed, because this game is one step above a text based game lol, but that's part if it's charm and addiction. So simple yet so much to do. If you enjoy a wide range of games then just buy this game and thank me later, but if you're a picky gamer who only enjoys a single genre of games (All Sports/Action/CoD) then keep walking, this will bore you.

This is a fantastic game that'll keep you coming back for more as you try to prove yourself in the competetive Game Industry and bring your company to fame and fortune.  It starts you off with the simple premise that you are a fledgling Game Developer trying to make a name for yourself in the still infantile Gaming World back in the 1980s. From there on out you have to use your limited budget to try and develop games, grow your fanbase, and hopefully move your company out of your parents garage.  The gameplay is rather simple and user-friendly which is fantastic for the beginning player but can get a tad tedious once you're on your 7th or 8th run through of the game, that's not to say it makes the game less enjoyable but it would have definitely been a plus if the game let you get a little more hands-on at points. As the game progresses you get to choose which consoles you want to purchase a developing license for, as well as create new game engines as new technology becomes available to you. Careful portioning of your budget is vital to gameplay and a rash spender will soon find themselves bankrupt and bought out.  The game is incredibly simple but has a fun, addictive quality that certainly kept me playing for a good long while and I'm sure that most of you will enjoy as well!

Oh man, where do I begin.   Game Dev Tycoon is one of the best simulation games I've ever played. It gives you a general feel of how the game industry has evolved throughout the years, parodying famous events, and has really immersive gameplay combined with that 'one more turn' feel from titles like Civilization V. I'd recommend it to anybody who likes, well, having fun.  Game Dev Tycoon sets you off in your own measly garage, making a 2D game. But as you make more and more games, you witness the world around you change: gaming becomes more popular, companies arise, and it becomes the next trend. The game portrays this transformation amazingly: you get to experience firsthand how the gaming industry morphed small developers into the giants of gaming today. Along this path, you manage your own gaming company, churning out titles that decide your company's fate, and, the gaming world's fate.  The gameplay in Game Dev is deceptively simple. You create games, with certain genres, and you allocate how much time each specific part needs (such as Level Design, or Engine). Over time, you learn what combinations create your AAA games, and what can give you the most money. Along the way, you add more features: Character Progression, Loading Screens, etc. Eventually, you'll be able to make giant projects, and more! Throughout this entire time, you also manage your staff, control marketing, and PR. It gives a very immersive experience in the simulation genre.  Furthermore, the game provides lots of replayability. Every new game start provides different scenarios, and you can tell the game to veer off course of what happened in reality. The Steam Workshop community provides even more: hundreds of mods for the game can change your experience, whether it be the addition of 'Next-Gen Consoles', or the pcmasterrace. The game goes way beyond the initial purchase, giving you endless opportunities.  Game Dev Tycoon may not be a AAA title, but it's definitely worth its price, and more. It features very immersive gameplay and storytelling, a fabulous community, and an overall well-designed game. Kudos to Greenheart Games for making one of my favourite simulation games of all time!

Extremely addictive and immersive. It tells a story about the turn of the century in which you are an independent studio and you alone decide whether or not your studio becomes a staple in the devs of the next generation or yesterday's news.  Pros: -immersive -original -true to the video game industry -versatility in what you want your dev team to be -30+ hours of quality entertainment -it's only 10$ so you get bang for your buck -developed by a small independent studio (not bad for a starting game) Cons: -limited replayability -there is no way to know whether or not your video game will be successful the only way to learn what works is with trial and error.   final score -7/10  9/10 if there was a way to boost research points,  however you can get research points (limited) for doing contract work without this feature the research mechanic seems lackluster.  10/10 if you could do surveys for your target audience to see what they would like in the game you're developing. Must have.

Pretty cool, pretty challenging. Start out as a one man team working from your garage, making video games. Work your way up in the industry (or crash and burn) as you advance in technology and hire more employees, creating games and game engines and other things as you play.

Game Dev Tycoon is a business simulation game in which you replay the history of the gaming industry by starting your own video game development company in the 80s. Create best selling games. Research new technologies and invent new game types.  I must say that it was preatty fun for me and still is. NOT waste of money:
You can make Game Dev Tycoon in Game Dev Tycoon  10/10

Ever since I started gaming, I've always wanted to try stepping into the shoes of one of those talented people who make games as a profession. Problem is, I'd have to go through hours and hours of dreadful tutorials of coding and meshing plus investing a respectable amount of cash in order to get my own project going. I'd also have to establish a lot of connections within the gaming community. Game Dev Tycoon skips the whole learning phase and gets you straight to the core: making games. Well... almost. While it limits your options for a game to just a genre and a few funny adjustable pillars, it does give you that authentic and exciting feel of building your own company and trying to rise up to the top of the pack. You also get to relive the history of video gaming with the rise and fall of real companies and consoles, building your titles on a wide variety of platforms from the NES to the PS4. Overall, it is a great experience for fans of video games and those who don't have the energy for making games in the real world. Just don't expect too much depth or choice in the actual creating.

This is accomplished by fighting legal incidents, attending to fans and managing projects. Even though this game does a lot of things right it also does quite a few things wrong aswell like not enough research and topics and some sort of online mode is missing here. These aside the game provides hours of time sunk into this game and is worth its price tag. Highly recommended unless you have a game like mad games tycoon. I rate this game a 7/10.

Overall this game is pretty fun, but it really does need some help; Things that need fixing; -bugs do too much to ruin your games, if you make a great game with only one bug you won't even make back a fraction of your money. This adds a frustrating lack of realism for the pursuit of gameplay, that really just makes it worse. Look at Skyrim and Fallout 4, they're buggy as hell, but are also two of the best-selling games of all time. -the reviewers are unrealisticly harsh. You can be setting records for your games in both Technology and Design, but you'll get reviews saying that the technology aspect 'Wasn't good enough.' They'll also say things like; 'the Genre and Topic were a great combination.' and then give you a rating of 4. -It needs a difficulty setting, that way it can be enjoyed by those that like to breeze through their games easily, and those that want to have to re-start their games 50 times before success comes their way. -It will make you game worse to have an aspect over-done. Since when is doing something well a bad thing? If a game type has Gameplay as 'not-important' but take your time and refine it anyway, it will somehow make your game worse. I simply cannot fathom how doing something better than it was can make a game worse. -More research points; research points are worth more than gold in this game, you simply cannot have enough of them. Also having making a game engine be the most lucrative source for them seems rather odd, seeing as how the main use for research points is new technologies for you game engines. Don't take the rant above as a bad sign it is sill a fun game, but it needs a little TLC.

Game Dev Tycoon is fun for about ten hours, but there's not a whole lot of replay value -- once you've beaten it, there's no reason to play it again. That said, there's a certain nostalgia factor in reliving the various eras of gaming.  The UI is buggy. Buttons and text fields frequently fail to catch your clicks, which causes the main menu to pop open underneath.  Overall, it's not bad for the price, but temper your expectations.

You are a game developer, working on your garage in the early years of gaming, developing from the old Commodore 64 to Ouya or XBox One. In the next 30-40 years you will grow side by side with the gaming industry, researching technology, design, marketing, and trying to make history.  Game Dev Tycoon is an addictive casual game, and although not so deep in the simulation aspect, provides a wide range of resources to manage, and to master this management you'll have to play it more than once, since the tips about how the market reacts to combinations of topic/genre/platform and time spent on each level of developing, still unlocked to the next playthrough.  What kind of game the market wants now? Which technology is better to use? May i spent more time on level design or artificial intelligence? May i have to create a new engine or research new topics? It's better to make it alone or it's time to move on to another work space and hire employees? Shall i spent more time creating games or studying? How about to have a boot at this year convention? Self-publishing or using a publisher? May i need to sue pirates, give away old engines or let the fans to make related games? That's some of the questions you'll face while playing.  About the flaws, the game have some, mostly because it needed more work to put together all this resources without compromising the gameplay. But facing it like a casual, cheap game, and learning how the game works, these flaws doesn't matter that much at the point of being big problems.

Here you absorbs the role as a lonley, inexperienced video game devloper from the early 80’s with the ambition to create video games and the possibility to make a futuristic, multi-billionaire, video game company.  And while you are fighting for recenition in the industry, you witness legendary hardwares throughout the ages: NES, Gameboy, Genesis, Playstation, Xbox- They are all here (and perhaps one day, your own console as well!).  You can carefully spend 30-40 hours on this game and still try to figure out how it works. It’s a strategy game to find out how to make the best combinations for the sufficent hardware for appropriate age. And make sure to not to get slaughtered the critics, hated by the fans or go bankrupt.

For a game looking like 'a peice of ♥♥♥♥' -Pro Call of Duty Fan, I LOVE it. The gameplay is organized, and doesn't give you to much freedom to make ultra big profits. I think that this game came from Greenlight, and i'm not surprised that it got picked to join the other millions of games on Steam. The ONLY problem with the game is that it doesn't have enough time. Now, this is a small problem, but I think in the future they should add a setting where you can continue your company even after the 30 years. This would be great because it would offer more things to the game like more platforms like the Play System 4, or even fictional platforms would be great. I could imagine an iPhone 8 being the size of an iPad. Oh, and I forgot, I hate the idea that you have different platforms to choose from. It's like, I'm making a strategy game, and PC is the best at strategy games, so whats the point? I guess it's that you get more interest, but that really didn't affect my games when I made a game for the PC and the Playsystem 3. Anyways, I love this game, and would recommend this game to whoever wants to make video games, cause this tells you alot, I mean ALOT. Except actually making video games, but you catch my drift.

I got this game the day it came out, I've gotten all the achievements. I've researched everything. Released 8 consoles. Made 34 engines. Created over 10,000 games and counting. Messed around with multiple mods. I have more than 70 hours on this game and I love it to bits, I have made the $10 worth it. The rating for this game is an understatment in my opinion. The games difficulty in some people's eyes foreshadows everything good in the game but aren't games suppose to be I challenge? I mean you don't want to beat a game in 2 minutes, games are suppose to give you a thrill and leave a lasting effect on you. People treat Game Dev Tycoon unfairly but give it a shot and I promise you will like it. Just because you don't make it the first time doesn't mean you should give up on the spot, you have to keep trying until you achieve success. Some people call this a Game Dev Story clone which I agree it is but in it's defence that game if for the iPhone,Android,etc. This is kind of like a PC port of it (of course better because you can mod), I truly enjoyed Game Dev Story but I enjoy Game Dev Tycoon even more. This game is a treasure and it should be recognized for it. Greenheart Games, you've made a masterpiece keep up the great work and I can't wait for your next game and maybe a DLC for Game Dev Tycoon.  10 - Their focus on Level Design served this game very well ...Star Games  10 - Oustanding achievement ...Informed Gamer  10 - Best of it's kind ...Game Hero  11 - 11 out of 10 Nuff Said ... I created a simulation of Electronic Arts...   I named my game engines after familiar names. We had Bullfrog, Westwood, Origin, Mythic, and Maxis. All of them were made derelect by my latest engine, which you can probably guess the name of. It was truly state of the art and brilliant. At least so I thought so. Had a team of really talented people.  Then, I had some issues with my games that I released with a lot of bugs tacked onto them. I was losing money and people are expensive to keep around. Unfortunately, I had to raise my hand and fire my talented employees that had been around for a long time and loved the company. Hired a wave of new guys.  Ended up losing a lot of fans after my games became abyssal. I guess the team of people I hired that were not specialized and straight with little experience were not good enough for what I wanted them to develop. I'm glad that the games I wanted to develop were really good ideas, or so I thought, so it definitely wasn't my idea! It isn't my fault that my buggy rehashes that lacked design wouldn't sell.   Went bankrupt because my fans hated me. Guess I should've fired my talented people and made my latest engine derelect sooner.  10/10, would simulate the gaming community's heartache, again.

This game is a fantastic indie economy game, where they successfully made it feel like things you do can impact the entire video game industry. My absolute favourite part is the fact that this game follows the way the industry grew and evolved from the comodore 64 days all the way to present day game development. I'll recommend this at 4 bucks, with a few caveats. This game is so close to being a great game. With just a few UI changes and some optimization, this would be a fantastic game. It's a great 'have a cup of coffee and play for a while' sort of game. You can easily hop in and out of it, and entire games don't take more than an hour or so.  Problems:  1. It runs *way* slower than it should, given how simplistic the assets are. Pretty horribly optimized.  2. Annoying menus that constantly pop up in a 'news feed' sort of fashion. They should be on the side of the screen and not stop/effect your game play. This is the single biggest reason I don't play this game any more. It becomes more and more tedious with time.  Those shortcomings aside, I'd still happily buy it for that amount. You'll probably get 20 hours out of it.

If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.  Ingredients: 1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter 2. 1/2 cup white sugar 3. 1/2 cup brown sugar 4. 1/4 cup water 5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon 6. 1 pinch salt 7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced 8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie   Directions: 1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C). 2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside. 3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices. 4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal. 5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust. 6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

In Game Dev Tycoon you replay the history of the gaming industry by starting your own video game development company in the 80s. Create best selling games. Research new technologies and invent new game types. Become the leader of the market and gain worldwide fans.  Start in the 80s  Start your adventure in a small garage office in the 80s. Enjoy the hand-crafted level design while you develop your first simple games. Gain experience, unlock new options and create your first game engine.   Create games your way  In Game Dev Tycoon the decisions you make during development really matter. Decide which areas you want to focus on. Does your game need more gameplay or should you focus more on quests? These decisions will have a major impact on the success of your game.   Grow your company  Once you have successfully released a few games you can move into your own office and forge a world-class development team. Hire staff, train them and unlock new options.   Make larger more complex games  With experience and a good team, you can release larger, more complex games. Larger games bring new challenges and you will have to manage your team well to deliver hit games.

Game Dev Tycoon is a Simulation/Strategy game released by Greenheart Games.   For their first title, Game Dev Tycoon is a very well made game that does not miss a single detail about what goes on during the development of a video game. Countless hours were spent picking new combinations of genres, platforms, and target audiences, trying to create the perfect game!   A game with so many things to play with may seem intimidating to some, but Greenheart Games included an easy to follow tutorial that teaches you the ropes without making it feel as if you're having your hand held through the entire game. Game Dev Tycoon even gives your information on screen that will remind you which combos are best and which aspects are best for said combo. You can even carry those tips to new games and have an advantage on your second, third and even fourth play through.  I give it an 8.5/10.

This is a very fun game. The concept is wonderful, the topic selection is expansive, and outcomes can be massive. I personally wouldn't recommend it to a casual, as later on it becomes very unforgiving to mistakes. The only problem is the lack of feedback. You could get bad reviews, and wonder if it was the combination of everything, or the fact that your engine may be outdated. A little is cleaned up by generating game reports, but still, a lot is untouched that could be fixed by slightly more exstensive reviews. Same goes for positive reviews. Did you do good because it's a sequel on a new engine, or because you simply moved the sliders a bit more accuratley?  Oh yeah, and if you miss a game because of an outdated engine, you're pretty much screwed.  Overall, Game Dev Tycoon, while feedback could be touched up, is a fun, challenging game. It's a race against time and half the time you have no idea what's going to happen (unless you study up the wiki), and that element of surprise makes it that much better. Plus, it's defeaningly simple to install mods, so if you get bored of the normal game, well, guess what? There's more to be explored.  8/10

Though heavily inspired by Kairosoft's sleeper hit Game Dev Story, GDTycoon manages to improve on the formula in a way many 'copycats' can't. The algorithm for generating 'hit games' within the game requires more strategy that in Kairosoft's original, and takes a while to build up a definite rhythm. Other improvements include the ability to create MMOs, multigenre and multiplatform games, as well as a compelling soundtrack. By no means a perfect game, it's definitely worth its price and a solid entry in the business simulation genre. If it were ten dollars more, I personally couldn't justify the cost, but as it stands now, it's priced reasonably for the improvements it offers over Kairosoft's Game Dev Story. Arbitrary Score: 6/10

Game Dev Tycoon is a tycoon strategy game where you create your own game development company. You start as a guy/gal working out of a cramped garage in the 80's and as you create popular games you'll gradually grow until you have enough money for a new premises as well as the option to hire employees. As you continue to grow you'll be able to make bigger, better games, research new technology to gain an advantage, create your own MMOs and even create your own powerful game engines.  +Nice simple graphics +A lot of depth to it, especially as you unlock more things to do later in the game +A huge variety of topics to choose from when creating your game +A wide variety of consoles that come and go as time goes by +The market responds to games in a realistic way +Some good random events though there aren't enough of them +The game lets you grow your company at a natural rate and only allows you to expand when you have enough money +You can take publishing contracts or other freelance work to earn some extra money inbetween making games +You have a lot of control over your game as you can decide how much time is spent working on certain aspects/elements of the game, when working on larger games you can choose who works on what aspect +You can train yourself and your employees to be better at different skills which improves your games and improves how quickly they are made +The game keeps track of what topics and genres work well on what console and what elements of the game are most important +Very relaxing to play +Lots of replayability +Nice sound effects +Workshop support +Very low requirements to run it  -Once you've played it once nothing comes as a surprise such as when games consoles get taken of the market -The size your company can reach isn't overly big, it never gets any bigger than a medium indie team -Soundtrack is a bit repetitive at times  Verdict: 9  A fantastic game development strategy game with nice graphics, a lot of depth and a real feeling that you're in control. This is easily one of my favourite games on Steam and a game which you should definitely pick up if you're a fan of tycoon/strategy games.

Lets keep it simple. Cons:  1. Short. This game has a total of about 8 hours of playtime. 2. Buggy. Ok so maybe not buggy, but it could have a lot of optimization done. Toward the end it will really tax a lower end computer. And there are a few things I noticed that were just... inconvenent. 3. Easy to read. A lot of the procedures in the game (how it ranks the games you make, how well they do in the market, etc) were somewhat easy to follow. Luckily hidden enough so I couldnt tell exactly what to do to get exactly what I wanted, it still seems pretty simple.  Pros: 1. Addictive. Remeber that old Lemonaid Stand game everyone used to love? It's kinda like that, but x10. I was glued to my chair for the entirety of the day. 2. Replay Value. Maybe not for me personally, but there is a lot of potential in this game. It can go far, and you can log a lot of well entertained hours for a fairly cheap price. 3. Design. The music may be awful, but the visuals are appealing to say the least, and it has some clever values to it that I really enjoyed seeing in a game.  Overall I truly enjoyed this game. Whenever it showed a hint of getting monotonous or boring in any way, it threw a curve ball and had you working over here on something entirely different. It keeps you entertained all the way to the end, as short as it may be. However it did feel a little incomplete, and could use a couple patches.  Even with all that being said, and being (in my opinion) a tough judge, I have to give it at least an 8/10. It could use some updates for small annoying things here and there, and it was pretty short, but overall a fantastic game.

I bought this game on sale expecting a nice casual timewaster and I got that from it and more.  The gameplay starts off enjoyable, accessable and creative and gradually builds in complexity as you learn the ropes and unlock features. The late game is packed with features that will keep you entertained until the end. It's addictive gameplay and keeps you coming back for more.  As for drawbacks, I'm not sure the replayability is very strong. After playing a few successful games, you kind of feel like there is little deviation from the script. Sure, the topics available to you at the start are random every time and there are a couple of different ways to specialize your company but by the middle to late game, you're following the same sort of pattern as many other times before.  The time speed is set well at the start of the game but soon becomes a little too fast, not giving you enough time to appreciate the gameplay but forcing you to work quickly to keep up. This can be fun but I feel that in the later stages you should have time to consider your options more without having to pause the game. Often the R&D office is rushed and seems like a last minute part of the game rather than an integral feature. A player-adjustable time speed would be great for this.  The story progression is good, but it would be nice for your company to have some small impact on the way the market plays out. It can feel as though you're stuck in a bubble, with no visible competition from other companies and no impact of your company on the wider world. Competing companies and an interactive market would be great in this game, perhaps with different regions responding differently to your games.  The linear progression from office to office can harm replayability. Being able to choose different offices with different pro's and con's would make the game much more replayable and introducing choosable upgrades, even cosmetic ones, for your office would be great. I was really hoping I could spend the money I made to upgrade the car in the garage!  Overall this is a fantastic little game, with heaps of potential. It's addictive, full of features and enjoyable. I really really hope that the developers will expand on this and introduce some diversity and branching choices to make it more replayable.

Game Dev Tycoon is, much like it sounds, a simulation game about running your own game development company. You start off as a singular developer with your sparce savings working in your garage, eventually making enought money to hire on a few employees of your own, then moving into bigger offices with bigger companies and eventually even to making your own consoles. You can develop games for all the major consoles through the years, outfitting them with the latest innovations (if you can afford it!) and trying to build a gaming company that will last through the ages.   Most of the game is focused on developing games, and rightfully so. The development is less abstract creativity and more focused on allocating points properly; should you put more effort into dialogues or enemy AI for your adventure game? Do you have enough resources to develop both an AI companion and moral choices, or will budget and time contraints force you to cut one? The games are still abstract enough that they provide plenty of room for the player to fill in the gaps, however. You can create a studio known for groundbreaking horror adventures in one game and devote another to sprawling sci-fi shoot-em-ups. The various topics that are accessable without extensive research change each game, further encouraging players to play each studio differently and explore new genre and topic combinations.  Good as it is, I do wish the game had some sort of free play mode where you could just play around with developing games in a particular genre, or at least the ability to pick when in the storyline you wish to start. Reviewers tend to pan any games smaller in scope than your last ones, so mobile market? Forget it! By the time mobile games come along, a moderately successful developer won't even be able to break into the market, since all your games will have been larger scale endevors. I'd love to be able to play as a small developer trying to break into the indie market, or an upstart mobile dev that eventually makes the big time.  Overall, I recommend this game to fans of simulation titles. Whlie it has a few flaws and the rating system can force players to contantly be building bigger, it's become a solid game with a great deal of depth.

When this game came out, the devs deliberately leaked out a 'cracked' version to BitTorrent. It was the full game, plus an extra feature. At some point, the player's games would start to get pirated, lowering sales increasingly until no highly rated games could be made profitably. The people who pirated the game then went to the forums to do exactly what real world game developers did: Ask how the heck they could make a profit with that piracy in place, if they could add DRM, or take other measures to fight it because they couldn't keep their business going.  If an entertainment product manages to relay a message into the real world with such power that people emulate its behavior, it's a work of art in my book. Fight club did it before by making people emulate the 'You do not talk about fight club' slogan (because it would ruin the unique plot twists). This game did it through its remarkable method of making a statement about software piracy.   This game is a work of art. It deserves to be tried just for that.

An enjoyable one time ride 6/10  I loved game dev tycoon but sady it's not very replayable and once you produce your own personal game consul and AAA MMO, the game just losess all that excitment and fun that it had while trying to reach the top. I found it to be like a mmo game in the aspect that once you reach the max level and unlock all the features it's boring and you have nothing left to do but sit and get richer.  If I could figure out how to use the mod creator or create a mod myself I would deffinatly make a new office level. The level would be a sky scraper or tower with different floors, perhaps the first floor would be a shop that you could sell your games and customize/decorate it with items made by your company or decorations bought from in game shops. Maybe seperate the R&D lab into a floor and the research lab. Then make a floor dedicated to your empolyees with a lounge and work area with a few more desks than last time. Then perhaps a personal office for yourself. It would also be nice to have a virtual reallity or full emersion mod added to the game. I also feel like an event mod is needed to add a more emersive feel to the game. Such events as the one where when you come out with your first consul if it does well, when other competetors announce their new consuls a event message pops up saying let us see how it fairs against 'players consul'. I would love if they simply added more event messages like this so I would feel more involved in my gaming industry world.  But in the end I feel like rather than another mod fthis game could use an 'expansion pack' tat would add these things in, but sadly I'm afraid greenheartsgaming is not the kind of group that would do this kind of thing. For an example they went as far as to TROLL, yes TROLL, piraters who have no money with a fake game that would make it impossibly to beat as the game went on. Sadly this TROLL failed as a full pirated version did become available on the interenet but with no steam access.  I do look foward to games from this company but I don't hold my expectations high. Over all I recommend this game if your looking for a one time fun adventure threw the gaming industry world.

OK, let's get the bad stuff out of the way first.  1) The graphics are not AAA standard. In fact, it looks like a browser based Flash game from 10 years ago. 2) It's frustratingly random sometimes. 3) The stock game is quite limited, and you have to wait for the game itself to allow you to innovate through Research.  But forget all that. This game is, above all else, FUN. It's an enormous waste of time that sucks you in and doesn't spit you out for another six hours or so without even realising. And isn't that what games are all about? There is something enormously addictive & satisfying watching those little coloured balls 'schlup' into their respective bases.  I was involved in game development in the mid-80s (budget games on the C64), which is more or less where this game starts out, and whilst it doesn't claim to be a historical document or anything so grandiose as that, the way the game pans out is strikingly familiar to anyone of a certain age who was there.  The feeling you get when you strike upon a winning formula, the temptation to blow your windfall on that 'personal' game you've always wanted to write (only for it to flop dramatically thanks to some heartless reviews), whether to start the game slow'n'steady or go all out for that big hit. The decisions you make in this game are not always provided by the game itself, and that's what is so compelling about it. It's a lovely throwback to a time when games were as much about your own imagination as what is presented on screen.  In short, I love this game. It's a perfect example of what an 'indie' game should be, and my only hope is that the developers have successfully managed to research 'Sequels' and are busy working on one right now. If they are, one thing I would like to see is modular development - so you can add a couple of features to a game engine without having to invest the time & money re-writing everything from scratch.  Buy it.  10. Best of its kind.  -- Game Informer
