This is by far one of the most fun mini-sim games I've played. Excellent first title as by Greenheart Games - symbolically ambitious.   My first run through the game, I was feeling great. By around year 20 I just expanded my R&D division. My main game, Call of Doody (Mature Military Action) was making hit after hit. Cross Country Canada (Transport Sim) was in it's 5th installment with Hacky Sack (Sports sim) performing well along with a handful of other titles.   I made a critial mistake at this point and failed to keep up with the technology. I spent too much time training my employees to expand the business and sunk too much money into reseach on technologies. My game engine was in it's fourth edition but I didn't have enough new features to update it.  Slowly, one by one, my acclaimed titles shrivelled up. I threw sequel after sequel together only to be met with underwhelming reviews. I had to let go one of my employees and halt the development on MMO technology. I was in the red after a few lack luster releases. I threw everything I had at Call of Doody 5, only to met with an resounding 'meh' by the reviewers. In a last ditch attempt I pieced together an update on my game engine but it was too late - the banks came knocking and the development never finished.   The unease and disappointment sat heavy in my stomach. My company was out no more.  This game gave me a serious case of the feels and for that, a solid recommendation.

A game development company simulator that mirrors real-life historic game industry happenings. Also easily moddable to add or create your own consoles and such. It's fun if you take it just at that, but consistent success is infuriatingly difficult to grasp.  You are essentially playing to always get a higher score than your last so it benefits a player to sabotage their own success as they go in order to continue to achieve high reviews. The goals and values to be reached in order to get good reviews are all hidden and unclear. It is to your benefit to read a guide and play with some of the data tables open.  Two of the achievements are just ludicrous and seem to be wholly luck-based. One involves getting a value the game is seemingly coded not to produce with a score of 11/10? The other requires a sales total for a single game of 100 million or more which is excessively time consuming and nearly impossible if you didn't play correctly from the start, pacing your success by sabotaging yourself in order to maintain high scores and build a larger fanbase. It's ridiculous to the point where hacking game saves seems a more reasonable alternative to get those. The other achievements are far more reasonable, although the perfect 10 achievement also seems unreasonably luck-based.

Pros: +Very addictive +Very fun +Nice to see the road from being a one man studio to being a succesful company +Lets your creativity flow freely (except if you suck then you go bankrupt and your life sucks)  Cons: -Gets repetitive after multiple playthroughs -You kinda end up always going for the same game genres/style to dodge bad ratings -Some combinations should work but still give horrible ratings when dumb ones become GOTY  I first played this game on a friend's computer after a party when I was still drunk. Made me want to own the game for myself and decided to buy it when it was on sale. Played through and I gotta say, this is one of the best tycoon games I've played. Even though it can seem a bit shallow since you always stay in one spot, the game keeps you entertained by adding new consoles or shutting down some making you think through your game releases. It can also get pretty funny as a ''party game'' with friends where you come up with ♥♥♥♥♥♥ names for games to then see them rise to the top of selling charts and to then have them known has your studio's biggest success.  Would recommend it even at full price for all tycoon/simulation lovers out there.

Game Dev Tycoon is a simple yet rewarding tycoon game. Start out as a game developer working in your garage and become a game dev legend. The progression is almost historical in nature, you begin in the 80s with the ability to make low level 2D or text based games, once you begin to make some money you can research and develop better games. As time goes by new consoles hit the market and the demand for better games grows with them.  The only thing missing is a sandbox mode, but once you reach the end of the campaign you can continue developing more games and researching more technologies (maybe even developing your own console!), so that pretty much covers it!  Game dev Tycoon is a creative and rewarding experience I would happily revisit over again. It's colourful and inspiring and still manages to surprise me. That is why I recommend it to any tycoon lover!

When I first started playing Game Dev Tycoon I initially thought it might be quite easy as I was making quite alot of money, But as I progressed and upgraded I found out it was just luck and soon realised there might be more of a challenge after all.  Game dynamics are actually very complex with 6 genres and 52 topics and several systems finding the right combination can be difficult, when you find the right combinations they can be carried through to new games which significantly increases replay-ability if only to collect all combos and increase success in future games.  I have come across a few bugs that have crashed the game but assuming like me you save regularly this isn't a huge problem.  To sum up I would give this game 8/10 - well worth the money especially if you get in a sale as I did.

Game Dev Tycoon, I bought this game back when it first came out in the beginning of April of last year. It is a really fun game.   Game Dev Tycoon the good: The gameplay in game dev tycoon is where it shines, in game dev tycoon you are a game developer starting out in a garage in somewhere USA, working to become one of the best game makers of all time. When you first start out there's 4 topics to choose from, and you learn more topics to do by researching them. Researching requires research points, don't have enough research points you gotta wait. Once you get into a higher place you can hire staff so your character doesn't have to do all the work and you can make bigger games and it can come faster. The final level really pays off and it's where you can make a lot of money, you can make your own console. You can also make your own MMO and your own version of steam, called 'GRID', make your own convention as well through the R&D and Lab, there are also tons of mods on the Greenheart Games forums that will increase your gameplay experience, such as expansions, cheat mods, real names for consoles and multiplayer! Game dev Tycoon shines in the modding aspect. Now for the bad  Game Dev Tycoon feels like a guessing game/ wiki game you either, have to guess how to make a good game, sliding up and down random bars for different parts of the game. Or you have to reasearch it on the game dev tycoon wiki. It requires a lot of guesswork. You also don't know what the outcome of your game is. You can't even make a backstory even out of predetermined words. The interviews as well don't really let you choose what they are going to say, and you can't really tell what the reviews mean the reviews are absolutely useless.  Overall: Game Dev Tycoon is a really great indie game, hopefully if they make an expansion or put Game Dev Tycoon 2 out it will be better, Game Dev Tycoon is a 8.5/10 and for 9 bucks it's super cheap for the amount of time you are going to spend on it. It is addicting.

As a non-game designer Game Dev Tycoon really puts things into perspective as to how difficult it can be to run a successful gaming company .Obviously there is a lot more that goes into producing a game, but it’s quite difficult balancing areas of game development (should I focus put more money/time into graphics or sound?), advertising (is it worth spending all that money on a booth at a game convention?), and what platforms to develop for (does a casual game do better on a PC or a GameBoy?). And Game Dev Tycoon lays out these choices in a manner which is fun to play.  Still, after about 10 hours or so of gameplay, I think I’ve had enough. Unfortunately, there aren’t enough new elements to keep me playing in the late stages of the game. You’re almost forced to continue developing games over and over again for a source of income, but after doing this 40+ times I get the point (different options for MMOs, AAA games, etc. are added but the basic idea is exactly the same).  It’s an enjoyable game that I recommend it. Just don’t bet on playing it for more than a dozen or so hours.  My rating: 3/5

But ultimately, great game, I would recommend if you enjoy hours of fun.

Aaalrighty then... What can be said about this ? This is problematic because the game is great if you look at it by its concept, but everything else is... Lackluster at best. I am trying my best not to sound biased, because i really enjoyed the game for what it was. But at the same time i also disliked it because of its mechanics, so i'm very between two opinions at the moment.  For starters i really didnt pay attention to the games history, only thing i know about it that its the studios first game and it was on Windows store, which if my memory serves was only on Win8.    No wonder people havent heard of it very much, before it went on STEAM anyway..    For the studios FIRST game this is a good example of stuff to come, however it has flaws in it and it felt rushed out. This was before the patch they published that repaired some of the issues. But even after said patch, the game still feels... Broken. Lets see if i can atleast explain those flaws and reason if there is a redeeming factor in it.  Graphics  The graphical style can be easily compared to several Facebook-games    Feel free to shout at me for that   , which i really cannot critique because it was the aesthetical choice. The game has a lot of colour, but unfortunately its sometimes too bright, thats if you play it in a dimly lit room. And the game also seems have some issues regarding the UI, it seems to be designed for a single resolution and it does not scale. when you play it in windowed-mode it breaks the UI 95% of the time if you dont set the window to certain proportions. However even with its problems the graphical design of the game serves its purpose of being nice to look at and it doesnt bore you easily untill you have played it into 'completion' atleast 5 times.   Music  There is not many musical tracks in this game and what there is, gets boring very easily. There are not many FX-sounds either. Besides clicking and 'blip' noices that the 'bubbles' do.   Gameplay  Well.. The gameplay is pretty much as it is in many other SIM/TYCOON-games, in that it has little interaction besides ticking boxes, watching the 'bubbles' gather and select the gategory ang genre of the games to develop. Later down the line, you have the option of making your own console. which sounds great, if it didnt have a problem of not showing the expected sales so you can atleast quess if developing your own 'Uber-underpowered-pc-mediacenter-w*nkbucket' would be worth the money it costs to make.  There also is the option of greating an MMO-game, which unfortunately has the same problems as the MMO's in real life. That is its needs to be that certain genre to actually appeal to the masses.    atleast for what i noticed, you would think that a M-rated Action-MMO with a decently lewd name would be awesome, but no.     The biggest problem that this game has, is that it gives almost no feedback. It was 'fixed' in the patch, but even with that its still a cr*pshoot if you actually set the sliders to their correct positions when you set the focus on development, even with the 'feedback' given by the Game-Report.   Did i miss something?... I think i didnt miss anything vital, i hope.   Conclusion  Although the game is flawed, it is still fun. I really cannot explain it, maybe because i was such a fan of Tycoon-games and The Sims, back in the day... But even with my slightly bias opinion, i really cannot overlook the obvious flaws that this game has.  I also dislike STEAM, because it doesnt give a third option when making a recommendation. I could easily give this game a 5/10 or something else in the middle, however i'm forced to only 'yes and no'. Ayyeeegghh.....  So because the game is flawed, and STEAM recommendation system is terrible. Against my better judgement, i am forced to give this game a thumbs up.

This. Game. Is. Awesome.   A truly inspired concept, for everyone who has thought to themselves, 'I could totally make an awesome game'. Very easy to learn, Extremely hard to truly master. Create inspired games with carefully crafted gameplay, graphics, sound, storylines, engines, the lot! Or...♥♥♥♥ about and create games with stupid titles! Be Bethesda or EA, it's completely up to you!  The mods available for this game just expand an already incredibly immerseive experience, play the vanilla first though.   Just...buy this game. You'll not regret it.

Made a Romantic/Vampire Simulation game called 'I'm Here To Suck Your Dong' and recieved a perfect 1,  10/10  But in all seriousness, this game is wonderful and I'd reccomend it to anyone.  It allows you to do what we all wish we could do; develop games!  It supplies that in a very nice way by using research to find new topics, modifications to add to your personal game engine, and train your workers/self to make even better games.  There is a subtle humour in the game by way of phony names such as Stephen Jobson as a designer, to having little easter eggs that I am not going to spoil. While the creation part of the game is a little bit of a learning curve, once you grasp the hang of it (Or use guides ;) ) it becomes a lot of fun to play. The feeling of reaching a perfect 10 score for a game you marketed like crazy and spent all your money on is the best, along with the incoming millions it brings. The progression is nice, the progression from the first office to the second takes a bit long for my taste. Having you make psuedo-strategic decisions in how you'll market or represent your game is a really nice touch and makes it more fun.  In all honesty I will give this game a 9/10 just because I feel like the creation part of it could be a bit more in depth. The simple sliders just doesn't do enough for me.

I'm several hours into Game Deve Tycoon and while it has been fun, there are some problems. Some of the writing is pretty funny, and the game is pretty addicting, but it feels like some of the gameplay should have been a bit more refined. You can't slow down or pause time to give commands to your employees, and after a game is released the popups and interruptions can fly at you pretty fast. Better analysis options in the game history would be fantastic; as it is, you can only scroll through your previous games in chronological order, but sorting by ranking, sales, profits, types, etc would be really useful. It's also oddly resource intensive, given that there are no complex graphics involved. And you can't change the screen resolution or display size, so whether I have the game in fullscreen or windowed, it still cuts off part of the screen. Still, I'd recommend it as a fun timewaster, and if you like Steam games, you're probably the kind of person who would love to pretend to be a game developer. Falls a bit short, but fun and it's probably worth a sale price.

There is a game in the back of every gamer's mind, festering, waiting to claw it's way out. An idealistic title, that the world simply isn't ready for. The time is now, joystick warrior. You enter your garage, walk past your rarely driven Delorian and face your greatest challenge. Creating the ultimate game, the one game that will put your company on the map, and change gaming history forever.    Game Dev Tycoon is the vehicle that will deliver you to your ultimate game creation fantasies, and does so brilliantly. As with all great indie developers, your journey begins modestly in the comfort of your garage. Though hours later, you may find yourself in a modern office, with a full staff maintaining the worlds greatest MMORPG. From reviews, to sales charts, this title takes you through every step in the process, for better or for worse. Gone are the days of complex simulations, streamlined and simple, Game Dev Tycoon delivers a casual, yet complete experience.   Do not let buzzwords like casual fool you though, I was still able to extract roughly eight hours of much needed escapism from this game, and had an absolute blast doing it. This game takes the addicting game-play at the core of every tycoon game and presents it in a fresh, easy to swallow, manner. Not to mention stuffed full of personality, gaming history, and love. What else would you expect from a developer by the name of Green Heart Games?   From R&D, to marketing campaigns and creating your own console, this game runs the gamut of the video game industry from past, to present, and beyond. Can you steal market-share from the Xbox One and PlayStation 4? Or will your company go bankrupt trying to launch your next-gen MMO? It all comes down to your elite, or not so elite, management skills.    THE FINAL VERDICT   Overall this is a great title, and well worth the spare change you will spend on it. Polished graphics, straight forward, but challenging game-play are hard at work here. Complimented by great tone and sense of humor. Any hardcore gaming fan will love this tile. Though, buyer beware, this game WILL take many hours away from tending to your humanly duties. You might want to consider using that sick day you've been saving up for that next Call of Duty launch.   You can read the original review   Here   [www.pixelsforbreakfast.net]   You can also view more of my work   Here   [www.jamesabels.net]

DONT RUIN IT FOR YOURSELF. My warning to beginners  Game Dev Tycoon can be a fun game and even an immersive one if you give it the chance. My recommendation to anyone who wants to see this game as the developers intended is to play your first play through without looking up anything, will your results suffer for it, yes, but it gives you the feeling of an unpredictable market. My biggest warning to people trying this game is not to dive into its mechanics, all of which can easily be found online. I did this about half way through my first play through and it really does kill the experience. Ive seen people complain about it and I will agree that the system by which games are judged is a little silly at its core and can easily be manipulated to have yourself spitting out perfect games left and right. But at this point you've just turned it into a very shallow experience of number manipulation. If you take this game as its meant to be played there is a lot of fun, nostalgia, and some humor to be had and should keep you busy long enough to justify its price.

I bought this game on the Autumn Sale (or Spring Sale if you are in the southern hemisphere). Upon starting the game, I loved it. The concept of playing as the leader of a future (or bankrupt) gaming developer company, sounds amazing. I personally love simulator/tycoon games, this satisfies my likes. It is very fun; although, heavily inspired by Game Dev Story. I played this for hours when I bought it. It's a fast download, even with my terrible internet. I enjoy having a note in the game about the devs appreciating my purchase; makes me feel like I did good. I recommend this game to those who wonder what it would be like to be a game developer. While the game is somewhat simplistic, there is a lot of features and decisions you must make; whether it's deciding to sue loyal fans pirating your game or sabotaging competitors. The game has settings that make it either a long-term or short-term play style, depending on what you prefer. There is an array of options when developing a game, whether it's a Hospital / Advenure game or a Vocabulary / Action game for Mature. Getting a 10 on a review is highly satisfying, especially when my 'Call of Honor' game released. The game doesn't disappoint.  TL;DR Fun game with a lot of choices and consequences.

Game Dev Tycoon puts you in the shoes of a budding game developer working out of their garage in the 60's and challenges you to work your way up the ladder to become one of the top entertainment companies of the industry. This game is very creative, and innovative, and has alot of fun gameplay allowing you to experiment allover the place in hopes you can find a miracle hit that will sweep the world by storm and make you millions. It is also a great historical review of the development of the gaming industry, starting with the original NES release, although they re-name everything with fun paraody names, the core historical content is there, and it's a great insight into how things happened in the past, while allowing you to be an active part of it. I have really enjoyed this game throughly, and I recommend it to anyone who wants something new and interesting to play.  <minor spoilers here> It would not be a fair review without also telling you about some of the negatives as well. In the case of Game Dev Tycoon it has alot of innovation but some of the features seem a little shortened and could have used more development. The way you publish and maintain MMOs seems lacking in real development and doesn't seem to be well thought out. They constantly raise the maintenance costs rather then having them reflect more realistically the cost to maintain certain numbers of users or even allowing you to choose how much budget to invest in the maintenance of the game yourself. Instead, the maintance costs go up every month until there's no way sales can pay for the maintenance, and you have to release an expansion pack, which will reset the maintenance cost for awhile, but it starts going back up again. I don't find this to be at all an accurate model of how an MMO's maintenance runs.   Another issue is with the scoring system, instead of being a more logical system it instead forces you to go against your own internal 'high score' which uses an obfuscated algorithim to calculate the final reviewer score that will determine your sales and popularity with any particular title. It seems like they didn't want it to be straightforward, or just impossible to predict. The algorithim rewards consistency instead of innovation and creativity...it's literally better if you stick to a generally same performance rather then strive to be better. I don't understand how that's a realistic model either.   They also seem to have forgotten about things like crowd funding, gnu licensce releases, focus groups, playtesting, the puzzle genre, and other details that would flesh it out massively.  Building a console in the game is a sadly simple process that isn't really that...fun. You pick a name, what graphics engine it will feature, and choose from a set of premade variations and that's it. You can't elect to use motion controllers, or a kinect kind of system..there's no options to modularly design it yourself, etc. I find it extremely limited.   The game seems to be missing alot of extra management stuff, in MMo's, console releases, and even the Digital Distribution platform you can make... I would very much like to see this game fleshed out much further through DLC or a sequel. If I were them, I would take most of the money they made from this game release, and re-invest it into making a better one now that they have more capital. (I do it in the game all the time!)  In light of some of the limitations and negatives, I still recommend this game and I still very much enjoy it within the scope that is has. However, I would not pay 10 bucks for this, so if you are considering purchasing this title, I would suggest you wait for a sale.

This game is very creative. Anyone who has ever wanted to make games when they get a job will really like this game. There are so many choices to make in the game. For example, you can choose: what kind of game you make, what it will be like, who works on what part of said game, etc. Also, the campaign is about 40-45 years of in-game time. You can play this game again and again and make different choices every time. If you play this game, you will know what I mean. At the price point of $10, some people might say it's too expensive. Game Dev Tycoon is a fun game to kill a couple of days with. It is not easy, and I found that I went bankrupt the first couple of times after my first move. It provides some challenge, and that keeps the replay value up.  Obviously, there are many omages to the history of gaming, particularly console gaming, and that is fun to read the first time. However, after you play through it once, you will be skipping through those. That being said, the challenge of creating new and varied games will keep you coming back for a good little while.  My only complaint lies in the game creation algorithim. Becuase it is based on comparing your newest game to your previous best game, it can be difficult to consistently produce high level games. Sometimes, it feels like the gauge for a games ratings is a bit random, and you are surprised at both flops and successes, but not in the good way.  I recommend it because there is enough to make it enjoyable for a number of playthroughs, and the price point isn't too bad, either. On sale, it is a good pick-up.

A more streamlined and Westernized version of the mobile app Game Dev Story by Kairosoft, Game Dev Tycoon is a wonderful time-sink for simulation and video game buffs alike. There is plenty of flexibility for the player in choosing which direction to take his or her fledgling game company from the early days of gaming to the hypothetical near-future. While not the deepest nor most complex game ever created, Game Dev Tycoon manages to fill the role of a great casual pastime for those of us with more than a little nostalgia for the gaming days of yore.

I've been a fan of the simulation/'casual' genre ever since the original Sim City and Oregon Trail were pixelated on PC. I decided to give this game a try and conquer the gaming world one release at a time.   The positives: Once you release a few hit games, things can take off rather quickly. Your money starts to grow, your fan base increases, and the elements you can use to improve your games is almost limitless. There are option mini missions in the form of 'contract work' and 'publisher deals', but which ask you to achieve a desired outcome, otherwise pay a severe penalty.   The negatives: The first hour or two of the game can be extremely boring. You have the option of about 4 genres of games to create and very little to do until your capital begins coming in. The other thing I'm not fond of is how a game/combination can go over so amazingly at one point and not much later sink like a rock. I can't even begin to count the number of times I thought I had a hit on my hands, only to have the game receive horrible reviews. Also, the lack of detail on subjects and genres doesn't help either. What exactly is a 'comedy' as it relates to video games? Or 'alternative history' for that matter?   Game Dev Tycoon is a great game that I've enjoyed playing thus far, but it does have it quirks. If you can look past the minor aggravations this game can cause, you'll be on your way to building a video game empire!

On the other hand, the idea of owning your own publishing company is so damn intriguing, and it's especially fun naming your games whatever you want and watching them sell like hotcakes when you earn a full board of 10's from the reviewing sites. I'd say that if you're interested in the premise, then Game Dev Tycoon is a game worth buying. After all, it's only ten dollars at regular price, and I have about 20 hours into it already considering I bought this a week ago. It's a cute little Tycoon game where you start off as a solo garage developer in the wake of the Videogame crash of '83. Your only options for publishing are the PC and the G=64 (Stand in the the Commodore 64, sorry Apple 2 and ZX Spectrum fans, you're outta luck) and you have a limited number of topics and game types you can develop.  As the game goes on, you gain research points for working on games and engines, which you can spend to research new topics, new game components and effects, and to train your character(s). This is all functional, but it's missing something. For one, the only way to gain research points is to make a game or develop an engine (you also get a small number for doing a post-mortem on your game, but I consider that part of the development process). This means that when your game is complete, you can learn new techniques to put in your engine, which gives you more research which... well, you can't research anything and put it in your engine unless you do two engine builds between games, which is just silly.   In fact, it's actually more efficient to go several cycles on an engine and only update it when you have a good number of things to add. However, doing this leaves you with fewer research points, and on and on it goes. It's not really that big of a deal, and I do appreciate a balancing act in resource management in my tycoon games, but the structure and pacing of this one just feels off.  The second issue with the game comes up as a weird interface quirk after you move out of the garage and hire a team of developers to work for you. The game tells you that you need to periodically send your employees on vacation in order to keep them fresh, but the stamina meter is not really intuitive (it only shows up at all when they're close to being fatigued, and there is no tooltip if you hover over it to see what this unmarked meter means) and is exacerbated by the game giving you only the most cryptic of clues that this is affecting their performance.   After developing a couple games, your employees will stop contributing or gaining experience. When running your post-mortem, the game will tell you, 'You should include your entire team in the development of your games,' even though you very clearly did just include them all. What this actually means is that while you included them, they didn't contribute due to fatigue. It's a very bad bit of interface messaging. This is further exacerbated by the other problem with the Vacation interface. You only get the option to them on vacation when they have reach a level close to fatigue, So you can start development on a game with no indication that they're fatigued, and then by the end of development, they run out of gas and your game tanks as a result.   You can also only send them on vacation by clicking each character and choosing the 'send on vacation' option from the menu. There is no option to send them all at once, which becomes problematic when you expand your operation. Different developers will get fatigued at different times when they aren't hired together, and it can take years, and multiple botched or degraded games to get them all in sync again when you hire a new team member.   The ideal cycle for vacations seems to be Make game - Do Research - Build Engine, and by this point, they should start showing a fatigue meter, so you send them all out before starting development on the next game. However, as previously discussed, building an engine after every game is a huge waste of money, so you basically have to just sit there and do some crappy contract work or nothing at all until they're ready to send out. The game could have been made much better by including a 'Send whole team on vacation' option at any point.   Beyond those issues, it's a cute little game that hits a lot of nostalgia buttons, even if it does leave out several entire consoles (Sorry Saturn and GBA - Get ♥♥♥♥ed) while bizarrely including an announcement of the SNES CD attachment from Sony, and canceling it a day later. I enjoyed building my little game empire once I figured out how to manage vacations, and ended the game with almost a billion dollars stashed away and a portfolio including several 15Million+ sellers. It does become a bit formulaic, as you do a couple new ideas looking for a new hit franchise, then switch back to the safe sequels to prior hits every few game cycles.   One other minor quibble it that it seems like the game rewards you for creating the 'most' game, rather than the best one. You're basically never better off creating a smaller game once you make a decent bigger one. Including every single latest-and-greatest option in every game seems to be the best way to success, even if those options make absolutely no sense for the game you're creating. (Transport Simulation with advanced dialog trees, moral choices, and as many cinematic cutscenes as you can get - GO!) I guess in a way it could be taken as a meta-commentary on the people who buy games, but it doesn't make this game any better mechanically as a result. You pretty much have to make the biggest thing you possibly can every single time or you get 1s and 2s when it comes to review time.

Game Dev Tycoon offers exactly what you expect it to offer - a wide variety of games to develop, features to research, conventions to attend and eventually consoles to build. Whilst after the first hour or so you should be able to find your footing, beginners may find the game to initially be unforgiving and very much a matter of trial and error.  The playtime for a 'campaign' should be between 8 and 10 hours, so this is great for those who don't feel like investing too much time in this game. Unfortunately some people might not find the game to hold that much in the way of replay value, so I suggest waiting for Game Dev Tycoon to go on sale before investing.  The graphics are perfectly fine, though players might find themselves wishing there were more options to customise the look and feel of the game. There also aren't that many settings, though the game runs fine for the most part so most people won't run into problems. You're blessed with a windowed option so you can keep checking the wiki for guides!  The sounds are great - the popping of design and technology bubbles as you make a game is the audio equivalent of bubblewrap. The ka-ching sound you'll hear as your brainchildren enter the market also help to make the game an incredibly awarding and addictive experience. Unfortunately the soundtrack leaves a little to be desired, but I don't think anyone going into this is going to care.  Overall it's a decent game - maybe wait for a sale, but it's a nice way to spend a lazy afternoon.

So, I picked this game up in a sale, figured I would try it. I open it up a month later, after a long shift at work. I figure I can kill and hour or two until a friend comes online to chat. Sometime later I note my friend is sending me messages, and decide it can wait a few minutes, at least until I finish with the current game my team is working on. The next thing I know, the sun is rising, my family is waking up, my friend went to sleep three hours ago, I suddenly have 45% of the achievements for this game without actually checking the list, and I've somehow been sitting here for eight hours. I'm sort of afraid to check the achievement list, because I think that may cause me to lose track of a full week, maybe even more.

8.5/10  Picked up this game for $5 and holy shneikies this game is amazing. Played it for about 3 and a half hours upon first trying it. It's a game for people that like to pick up a game for a few minutes and save the game for later (I would imagine this could run on a Surface Pro 2) or you could play it on your beastly rig and gamed like I have for a few hours at a time.   Pros - Increadibly gripping experience - Sliders for the main choices ingame, any other system would have made it a bit too tedious - UI is intuitive and simple, yet brings out a lot of information - Good selection of choices on which areas to improve (ie: You want to improve your employees with training or do you want to improve your company by getting that new game engine pumped out for your next game release?)  Cons - Can be challenging, especially later on in the game if you didn't set up a good cash safety net  I would recommend getting this game when it's on sale for $5 or less.

'Well, this doesn't look so good, seems some cheap Facebook game meant to make you click click click til you run out of clicks and then tells you to come back tomorrow.' Was I wrong. While not really appealing on the eye, my first impact with this game thoroughly tested my old-and-new school game knowledge. And then asked me to guess which priorities I should set for five or six basic genres of games, not counting the multi-genre. And the answer is not simple, 'cause this game wants you to answer by moving sliders, research stuff and putting features in games. All that while making money and watching the options exponentially proliferate. This calls for an example. It's 1984, you're developing an action game for the C64 with some aliens in it, and you know you're going to invest some extra effort in basic 2D Graphics, and maybe you should put a Savegame feature in, or even some tutorial, and let's not forget about AI, because nothing says 'boss fight' like a changing move and attack pattern. Now, you're in 2014, developing a Post-Apocalyptic-themed Action-RPG, and after seriously thinking about multiplatform, you chose to save money and keep it a PS4 exclusive. The genre alone is very well received on that particular console. You should surely include features like advanced physics and mod support, skill trees and character progression, dynamic environment and the absence of loading screens, AI companions and some spectacular graphics... But that's not all. Should you make it single player, online play or plain MMO? Are you going to invest effort and resources in having a dynamic world, or maybe a virtual economy? How well written, acted and voiced will the dialogues be? That's what I meant for 'proliferating options' and believe me, that was the short version.  Only thing I miss, this game does have mod support, but I can't find one single mod that could intrigue me ad the original game did. I still hope to see something interesting there, anyway.

This is a fantastically addictive and highly replayable indie game. Gameplay largely revolves around efficient decision-making regarding how to spend your time and resources - should you focus on staff training, develop a new engine, or produce a blockbuster game? As you move through the 30 year history, big moments in gaming history are covered in a clever and funny way, and the game has a wonderful self-aware version of meta-humor. I highly recommend this game. The interface is fun to use, and the graphical style is quite inviting and accessible.

Out of the 7 hours I played this game, i managed to beat it.  Let me tell you this game is worth the 7 hours i played it. It teaches you about the game industy, it has all the pasts best consoles come on the market the accurat times they did in real life, and also had them exit the market the accurate times they did in real life as well. So it does teach you a lot about today and yesterdays consoles.  Pros -  This game has a great amount of time, not to long, not to short. Just right!!!  This game runs very smooth with no lag on high end. and low end PCs!!!  This game has a wide variety of things to do, and you have to unlock a lot of them making the story more fun!!!  This game has an amazing replay value, which i will defently replay this game and add hours!!!  This game has amazing mod support, and the workshop has some pretty wacky and useful mods to improve the game!!!   Cons -   This game can get a little buggy and laggy for some workshop mods, including cheat mods that improve money!!!  This game does not have that good of an ending, but i will let you guys find that out for yourselves!!!  This game does not really have anymore updates, but what can you expect from a two year old game!!!  This game can be played after beating the game, but it starts to get a little boring after you officially beat it endless you start a new game, (basically when you beat the game start a new one or else you will get real bored real quick!!!)   Thats all the game is defenetly more good than it is bad, and it is worth the 10$ you will spend on it. I already beat it in 7 hours but im not complaining that i cant get a refund because i want to continue playing this game. For those who bought this two years ago should still be playing it and for thoe who have not bought or played it yet get your wallet out and spare 10$ for this masterpiece, it is worth every penny and second of time you spend on it!!!

Man, this game is addictive. Whenever I play this game, I always tell my self that I'm going to stop an hour in. About 5 hours later, I blink my eyeballs for the first time since the beginning of the play session. I love the simple yet stimulating mechanics of this game. For example, your games that you create are given a rating ranging from 1-10 (and sometimes 11) after you complete it. Since you start out as a noob, of course you're going to get low to medium scores. The moment this game sucks you in is when a reviewer gives you a 7. I remember I fist bumped the air on my first 7. And it's this reward system that compliments the game's punishment system. Not only can you make hits, but you inevitably will make flops. There's nothing that hurts more than making a 3 game. I also liked how this game shows the pressures of an industry that we gamers often over look. Too many times in my life have I played a game and cursed out the developers for making a crap game for a quick buck. Well this game makes you understand why developers sell out to big publishers and making crappy games. It instills in you the stress of being on the verge of bankruptcy and having to fire your staff. I do have a couple of complaints with this game though. The entire game suggests that each genre of game has to conform to a structure. For example, an action game will not do well if you focus your energy on the story and an adventure game will not succeed if you focus time on the engine. This type of structure limits the creativity the art form brings, suggesting that games should be made with a similar formula. Also, the game includes a feature where you can create your own console. While neat, you cannot release any third party games on the system, leaving each console you make as the PS Vita (shots fired). It would be nice if the developers could incorporate a mechanic in which you are able to sign with a third party developer. Overall, this game is truly a delight. It gives you a sneak peak into the developer's world. Though it is slowed down by small details, the reward/punishment system and the immersiveness of the world more than makes up for it and will keep your eyes glued to the screen.

Don't read reviews...just purchasae. Stop reading...right now. Seriously stop.      Why you still reading? JUST BUY IT!!       Seriously?? FINE I'll give you your precious review! All jokes aside though this game is so much fun. It has a bit of a pattern to making games once you get the hang of it. I've put a lot of time and only did one play through that I am still on.   My company is worth $10 billion and shows NO signs of slowing down. Is it easy? No, its kinda hard to get 10/10 games but they launch your company's value and income. The management is fair and is pretty fun to manipulate and learn which things go with which genres. i.e World design, sound, graphics, etc.   You can make everything from mobile games to Massively Multi-Player Online games. Tons of genres to pick from and make games out of, and if you're like me with a good company you can afford to get goofy with the games.   It runs pretty solid, however I do have a nice system, and it runs well until you get a lot of 'bubbles' from the developement of a game going, then theres a bit of lag, but nothing to really make much of a difference.   So, there you have it. The damn review you just HAD to have.. Don't care if its not enough, it should be, NOW BUY, you can thank me later.

It's a game that will keep your attention for about 20 hours if you're trying to get all of the achievements. I'm still missing two after 17 hours, and they shouldn't be that hard to get the next time I play.  I think it comes a bit short since it's 11$. I don't feel like there is much replay value to it, it's always the same upgrades and the same story. Maybe if you like a challenge and try to get as far as possible before the 35th year in game you'd have some replay value, but that's pretty much the only thing I see.   It's fun for a couple of hours, but once you find something that works well, you just keep the formula, stack a lot of money and do the same thing over and over, pretty much. It gets very repetitive.  I'd say it's worth to buy if the game is on sale, not at full price.

I couldn't be happier with this game. All you could expect in a Game Dev Tycoon game. It's a typical Tycoon game, you make, design, your own games, and hope to have it be a success. After a couple successfull games you'll be able buy your own office, and employees to help discover new design techniques, and to help make, design. I myself havnt beaten yet, but have put several hours into it. The graphics are great for such a small easy designed game, its very simple, colourful, there arent many options to do much, but can still get addicting very fast, you make one successfull game and watch yourself make 2 mil in like 4 weeks. You can work your butt off to make a successful game to just get bumhurt by the reviewers. They can be very harsh sometimes, make you want to quit but slightly wanting to prove them wrong.   I would recommend this game, for those who want a small simple but addictive game, or for those who are interested in designing games(not that is shows you how too, but it does make you feel as if you are one).  I was also extremely bumhurt when naming my company PewDiePie. I could not design a single game. ):  (I couldn't come up with a name for my company, dont judge. Naming anything after Pewd's is always funny in a way)

Serving Size: 8  Category: Basic recipes, Breakfast, Budget, Cakes & Baking, Dessert, Easy recipes, Kids cooking, Kids food, Lunch box, Pancake recipes, Snacks  Prep Time: 5 mins  Cook Time: 10 mins  Ingredients: 1 cup (150g) self-raising flour 1 tbsp sugar 1 egg, lightly beaten 3/4 cup (180ml) milk 50g butter, melted Method: In a bowl mix flour and sugar.  Beat in the egg and then milk at little at a time until batter is smooth and lump-free.  In a hot pan or flat grill, brush butter over cooking surface and pour 1/4 cup measures for each pancake.  When large bubbles form on the surface, flip over and cook until lightly golden on the other side.

My Rating: 85/100  This game, at £6.99, is a bargain for the amount of gameplay you'll get out of it. I really enjoyed the depth of the development process, choosing exactly where to spend your points and what features to include (being limited by your budget and staff). I feel like it offers a fun yet complex experience and although it lacks true endgame, I've spent hours after my game's finished just developing high-quality games, without having to worry about budget as I've made all my money in the main game.  If you're into tycoons and are considering getting it, I'd say go for it. At £6.99 I've put more hours into it than some other £20 games.

Ah yes, Game Dev Tycoon. The game that I would play for either hours at a time, or for about 30 seconds before closing my laptop and forgetting the game ever existed.  It is a game of pointless grinding with no real sense of reward. It is a game of imagination with no real purpose. It is a game that exposes the true corruption of the gaming industry... It's a tycoon. It's just fun. One of the few tycoon games I've ever been able to actually get into.   TL;DR- good stuff if you like tycoons.

The progress to be a big company feels realistic, starts from your mom's garage all the way to your own company building, ofc it's not that easy irl but the game brings you a good satisfying feel when you earn big achievments. Worth every cent.

I can't really figure this one out. Ostensibly, this is a game along the lines of AeroBiz or Railroad Tycoon, where your job is to run a company and make lots of money, in this case by developing video games. It's got a cute, quirky aesthetic and some interesting pseudo-RPG elements, which is neat, but...  Well, frankly, this game seems incredibly, frustratingly random.  To wit; I spent about an hour bankrupting my company by making what seemed like completely rational, reasonable choices for a game developer to make. Making text adventures for the PC seemed like a good idea, for example. But it turns out text adventures are a dead-end because you can't level up other areas, which cripples you long-term. It also seems to penalize actual CREATIVITY; for example, I can think of a half-dozen awesome ways to do a Wild West-themed strategy game using SNES-level tech. However, Wild West and Strategy, as far as this game is concerned, Do Not Go Together, so no matter how WELL I make the game, it will tank in reviews and sell nothing.  Frustrated, I decided to look up guides of game/genre combos, and discovered that you pretty much have to make certain TYPES of games to have any chance of success. So, I tried again, this time slavishly obeying the standards of what genre/theme combos were optimal, setting development resources to the 'perfect' levels... and my games still tanked and sold like crap. The algorithm for how a game reviews seems to have NOTHING AT ALL to do with the actual Design and Tech points; I've had games in the 20s for Design and Tech earn millions and games where they were both high-60s get scores of 4s and 3s, during the SAME YEAR.  I feel like there's a significant difference between how the game ACTUALLY works and how the game TELLS YOU it works. Like, design and tech score obviously mean SOMETHING, but WHAT? There's no context for what '1 point of design' actually SIGNIFIES. And when you introduce the Hype Factor and the Review Scores, both of which are different numbers that are factored in different ways -it doesn't explain to you-, the result is a game where you're basically comparing three different types of numbers measured on three different scales which all clearly interact, but how that interaction actually occurs is completely opaque and arcane. Then you stack the game engine add-ons, none of which seem to ACTUALLY contribute much to overall finished product as much as 'not having this thing by this in-game year will tank your scores.' It doesn't feel like a game so much as a random number generator with pseudo-meaningful choices.  I can't make sense of this game. I tried playing it blind, and I tried playing it with a guide, and both options resulted in roughly the same end-result. As much as I like the concept and aesthetic, I just can't really recommend it.

This game was fun for a few hours. It may have been luck, or maybe it was my long love of RPGs, but I hit one out of the park and moved out of the garage after a couple of games. After that the game went stagnant:  * The history of gaming unfurls before you, in exactly the same way every time. It's cute to see the 'PlaySystem' launch or to see the 'Gameling' dominate mobile gaming for a long time, but putting a real-world analogue into the game is inviting meta analysis. I'd rather see random platforms and performance for an alternate universe feel.  * Once you get into the groove, the game becomes exactly as much fun as Microsoft Excel.  * The game tries to punish you for making the same game over and over, yet doesn't seem to encourage experimentation and risk-taking. I'm sure it's to do with my own playstyle and missteps, but my company was always one game away from bankruptcy, which made it tough to try that mBox Lawyer RPG instead of another iteration of Vampire RPG for the PC.

Creating a game in Game Dev Tycoon basically involves 3 steps:  1) Buying the best resources and technology you can afford (3D graphics, improved user interface, marketing, etc. 2) Conceptualizing the game by picking a topic and a genre 3) Devloping the game by adjusting several sliders to determine how much time and effort you put into each aspect of the game (graphics, sound, story, etc.)  The problem is that steps 2 and 3 often yield completely unexpected results and don't make much sense at all. For example, music and sounds are considered 'not important' for the RPG genre and putting any decent amount of resources into sound will result in a negative reaction from reviewers and low sales, despite how much acclaim RPGs get for having good music in the real world.  Topic/genre combinations often don't make sense either. Some combinations are obvious enough (racing/simulation, sports/simulation, space/action) but many aren't. How was I supposed to know that City RPGs are destined to fail or that Hospital Simulations are a great idea? You have the option of seeing all previously unlocked hints even when you start a new game, but when you know which games do well and which won't it defeats the purpose of playing.
This is a crappy ripoff of Game Dev Story, which can be bought on smartphones for a fraction of the price. This isn't even worth pirating.

On the surface, the game is great. If you play game like I do, however, and try to create the best game you can at all times, you will always go bankrupt a little ways into the game. It turns out the mechanics behind the review scores are absolutely abysmal. Rather than being compared against a current threshold for good games, they're calculated by comparing the score to the best game you have created thus far. If you create a 9-10 rated game, you pretty much just sabotaged your career, although it won't be immediately apparent.  In order to complete the game, you must always create games that are just a little better than the previous one, which, by the way, is much harder than it sounds as this is all calculated in the background. To summarize, it's a good idea but the mechanics are horrendous.
This game is lackluster, somewhat random in response, and can easily be 'beaten' by following certain formulas. I would not reccomend purchasing it for full price if you plan on buying it.

This is a simple and largely enjoyable game that I can't reccommend. Basically, it needs a little polish. For example: 1) the tutorial is impossible to turn off; 2) information from previous plays does not always carry over; 3) there is no option to make menu text appear instantly.   These may seem like small issues, but in a game that relies on clicking through menus, it's hard to accept all menus taking over a second to 'load'.   I'm happy to change my opinion on this one, the devs just need to spend a little time making the user experience more streamlined. Small fixes would go a long way (espeically in a game that rewards players for fixing their own games' bugs).

You get what you pay for with this. Bought it for $5 on sale and it doesn't offer much more than the number crunching aspect of running the business. Everything is a guess in the beginning as far as what topics fit with what genres, but after you figure out what works you can rotate combinations. I feel as though I'm playing beat the clock as opposed to working on creating good games. Time moves so quickly if you make consecutive mistakes you're likely to have a huge hole to dig yourself out of.  If you enjoy the number crunching aspect of some games this is worth the $5, but again you get what you pay for.

It wasn't an easy choice to give this game a thumbs down. I really want to like this game. I researched it, saw some people playing it on YouTube, read the comments about the non-intuitive choices and how they were supposedly fixed. Sad thing is that the game is still really non-intuitive, so I cringe at wondering how bad it was before. These are my thoughts, and I have NOT looked at any wikis for help on the game yet. I wanted to leave an unbiased opinion as a new player.  I'll start with the positives:  1. The graphics are cutesy, Flash-looking, what you'd expect on an iPhone game or a free online game.  2. The music is... ok.  3. I understand that the devs couldn't use certain copyrighted things, like the names of consoles, so the parodies are funny. (although if someone would just make a mod that renames all the consoles to what everyone knows they are it would be great.)  4. It's interesting to see console launches and deaths relative to each other based on real history.  5. There are a lot of choices to research, things to train your devs on, and genres / styles of games available.   Negatives / things I would change:  1. There are almost TOO many choices of things to research from the beginning of the game. I don't know if they dry up later, as I'm only on the 3rd or 4th office building. The overwhelming choices force you to pigeon-hole your company into specializing so you're constantly feeling limited, or leashed. I also had a hard time with researching new game genres to stay fresh vs researching new components to include in game engines. From what I can tell, certain choices / combos are worth way more than others, and since it's loosely based on history, if you make a romantic dating sim for the 'xbox' you aren't going to get anywhere, so why have these choices if it's based on history? This leads me to my next issue:  2. While the history is neat, it would be super kick ♥♥♥ if there was an optional setting to randomize launches and market share of upcoming consoles, so you don't know which ones you should support. It would add some RNG nightmares and I'm sure backing the wrong console could potentially bankrupt you sooner, but it would add a more realistic feel to the game. If you can unlock a mode like this eventually then disregard this statement. One thing that bothered me was that you start out with PC / C64, and then skip ahead to Nintendo. What happened to Atari or Intellivision? Rather than trying to show off these parodies of console we all know and love, I think the game could have been a lot stronger if this facet was randomized.  3. The game doesn't seem to have as much 'sim' as I'd like. You don't price your game at launch. You just 'finish' it and watch money trickle in. I'm not sure if games sell for different prices as you move on to newer consoles or if they're just a generic set price throughout the game. Having the ability to sell a game for cheap to gain market share / fans would have been nice. On the flipside, if you're cocky and think your game is going to get high reviews then you can price it higher. It would have been a nice feature to have. I also don't like the economy. The numbers seem to have been made in balance to itself, not based on real economic figures. I'm only a few office buildings in and I already have ~$100,000 per month in expenses, most notably paying my devs five to six figures PER MONTH. This is ridiculous, paying game devs a year's worth of salary per month. This is a huge oversight, and I'm sure they just threw it together like this to keep the game 'challenging' or something. It makes it hard to get a feel for what these fake dollars are really worth.  4. The genres and types of games you can make do end up giving you hints for the future, as to what works well together and what doesn't. What bothers me is how non-intuitive it is. You basically have to guess which combos are good, and then on what system, only learning after the game launches what works. What I don't like is that it's difficult to SEE what works well together unless you open up certain menus while creating your next game. If the UI would just open little popups when you mouseover something to give you more info on these sorts of stats it would make the game much smoother. Instead, you have to back out of menus and open other menus to see certain stats. You also can't just mouseover or click open stats of your devs, you have to open a screen as if you wanted to research something new to see their stats when all you really want to do is check their stats. If you could just mouseover the sections within the development stages to see the stats instead of the cryptic +++ or -- it would help so much.   5. There are NO confirmation menus. The game is kind of fast paced, and really it's a sim on game dev MANAGEMENT, not game development. You seem to have to spend more time on what your employees are doing than anything else. Every menu you open to choose something for the direction of the game you're making has no confirmation screen, so if you forget to include an option in your game engine, or forget to pick the right dev for a section of design, there are no Mulligans. You're stuck with a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ choice that could cost you millions, when all you need is a simple 'Continue?' box.  6. Time is constant unless you open a menu to pause the game. There is no pause button. You can't speed up or slow down time, and it does feel like it moves a little too fast, usually. Instead of a 'diner dash' type action game where you're trying to juggle choices, I'd rather have more sim than this arcade fast paced feel.   All these negative things put together do add up to an experience that could use a little more depth and a lot more intuition. Players shouldn't have to look up formulas on wikis to learn how to play the game better. Add in just a couple of little UI tweaks, and more depth to the simulation and you'll have a fantastic game instead of one that just goes through the motions like a cheap iPhone free to play game. I waited until the game was on sale for $5 and I do feel like it's still overpriced.  I'd wait on purchasing it until the devs add some kick ♥♥♥ updates or something.

A mostly text based time sink that would be great if it wasn't so mindless. You make games based on design and technical ability. You pick a genre, game type, platform, engine, and target audience. Then as time progresses you go through 3 phases of development. Each of the 3 phases have 3 areas you can have your developers put their time into. Every game type requires specific things from a developer. This is where the game gets mindless. Even though you can't make 2 games back to back of the same genre, you can have the same game type FOREVER. You can just make RPGs... and switch game genres from Sci-Fi to Dungeon or Medieval. The game lasts 35 years so its literally 35 years of just coming out with the same game. Between games you can train your developers, research things to help with your game engines or take on contract work for some extra money.... unless you fail.  Another giant issue I have with the game is there is no real randomization. Nintendo will always win the early video game wars, Gameboy will always stick around for far too long, and RPGs geared for young players will always dominate. oh and another giant issue is when you start out, you don't have a team of developers, you are just the only developer and ALWAYS at around year 4 you'll have a hit game that will thrust you into having a game studio.  Even though I've played through the game a few times for my love of management games. I always dominate the RPG portable market. I don't feel any sort of need to make anything else. Usually once the office gets larger, the game just gets boring. I'd love it if there was a randomization to ensure something makes each play through unique.  It is also interesting that on my laptop I had Game Dev Tycoon before it was on Steam and it worked. But with Steam the game doesn't work on my laptop. It works on my other two computers. Oh well.  In all I think people will love running their own game development studio, but in the end, this feels like a very hollow game. It has nice sounds and bubbles that move around making you feel good to see them flow up to the top. Its a nice touch for what is otherwise a static game with no movement, just menus.

It's hard to write a positive review for this game, even though I will say it is enjoyable and provides what it promises.   Simply put, I have some issues with Greenheart Games. It's not the content or the gameplay, and I'm sure they dedicated a lot of time and effort into it.   But this game has been done before.   For anyone that hasn't looked into it, Game Dev Story, out on mobile devices currently, has been around for quite some time, and while Greenheart has put JUST BARELY enough unique features and formats to make it different from it's ancestor, it has done very little to make it stand on it's own two feet.  It's overall a good ride, but I feel like it's one I just got off. And a simple homage, even a mere mention of Game Dev Story, would have probably made this game sit a lot better with me. But pawning it off as something they CREATED doesn't shine a positive light on the humble Greenheart.

My screenshots tell a lie, a story of minor joy at minor momentary successes. There is no value to any of my experiences with this game. There are too many ways to fail, and very little guidance is provided until you've invented that guidance for your future selves. The random selection of starting, and subsequent, genres is an unnecessary hindrance, and research points, for all of their uses, are far less common than they should be. Most of the fun comes far too late in a career's lifespan, and I have consistently been unable to access the research lab until around 10 years after the main game ended. There are methods to cheat the system, but if that's what I have to do to reach the good parts quicker, it's just not worth the effort.

The game is insanely fun for exactly one (fairly short) play though. I started around 3-4 games after the first one, but got bored and didn't finish any of those. It's fun, but shallow.  Overall I would recommend buying this game on sale, if not for the unfixable late-game lag. Not everyone experiences that, but from what I have gathered it is fairly widespread issue and it makes the game almost unplayable in the later stages. Devs don't seem to bother to address it.

Whether I would recommend this game is completely dependant on the reasons why someone might want to play it but since it only gives two options, I've gone for not recommending it.   The game is fun to a point. It allows you to feel like you're developing games, creating new franchises and consoles in your image, making the games you want become the best. However, this is about as far as it goes and in the later stages of the game this excitement at creating the games tends to get a little stale. To my first point, I would recommend this game if you got it while on sale and if you use it as a meaningless distraction, maybe on your break at work or something.   However, as a stand alone game with the aim to creating a gaming industry it falls a little short, if anywhere, on the rewards of such. As others have mentioned your games get rated based on a very sketchy out of ten by four different dudes that seem to have no particular focus on any aspects of the games. This scores then get based onto your previous games according to how good your previous title was and how good the current one is. While this can be realistic (come on, admit that you sometimes say a game is crap just because it's not as good as a previous game in that series despite that on it's own it would be considered pretty damn good) it doesn't add to the gameplay and instead serves as more of an annoyance and demotivator.  Most of the other features are pretty decent but nothing more than you would expect from a decent flash game. The effects of adding features to your game engine and then trying to implement it into your games are rarely noticed and I felt that if anything it restricted me from making the ideal game. I felt that there were too many moments that I had to sacrifice important aspects to a game in favour of others purely because they would not be completed on time. While I understand it's the developer basically saying that you can never get everything you want in a game otherwise it would take too long to produce, most of the features that I have to choose between I know are in pretty much most games nowadays so that still detracts from what we have in our world now.   Overall, this game is a decent crack at a unexplored mini genre (Game dev) with a well thought out game production process. However, there was a small problem in the execution and a couple of the feautres didn't really add to the gameplay and instead detracted from it. A good game when idling, but nothing to sit down to and play solidly.   If I had to give it a score I would put it around 5/10.

I was torn between recommending this game or not.   On one hand the game does what it says on the tin, but unfortunately that's all it really does.  The first play through of this game is very fun, but also very punishing.  You start with just you, your garage, and a default engine to create your first game. The games tutorial is very in depth, explaining to you pretty much everything you need to know to get started and there you are, on your way to being a massive developer.   The first problem for me arouse pretty quickly. The game has a set cycle. Every time you play it it WILL be the same. The game works by periodically releasing new consoles onto the market in the same order that the consoles were released at the same point each playthrough, and nothing changes. You see that console that you just bough a licence for at 1,000,000? Yeah well it's doomed to fail. Nothing you can do can prevent this thus taking any type of strategy out of the game. You'll find yourself either thinking back to which consoles flopped in real life or just remembering which consoles to avoid completely once you play through a second time.  I find this to be a huge flaw in a game like this. Simulation games should have some level of replayability and besides getting the achievements (which I actually think can be done in a single playthrough) there is none at all.  There are also some elements of the game which are not properly explained at all, such as releasing hardware along side an AAA game, what your expensive AAA marketing campaign does for your game and the proper structure of MMO's which can become frustrating but by the time I encountered these I was sitting on enough money to trial and error them a few times.  However, what is NOT Acceptable is that the game doesn't properly explain it's algorithm to you. Your game score is not based upon the game you make itself, rather the game compared to your previous games. As you can imagine the longer the game goes on, the harder it becomes to release a game that gets a score more than 5. I believe if you played this game indefinitely this algorithm would cause a point to come where it would be physically impossible to create any game with a good score, simply because you've done it before. I find this level of punishing past success to be offputting, and honestly, somewhat weird.   I think the game could have been greatly improved with a few minor features like randomizing the consoles success, market share and maybe even like Theme Hospital have 'competing' companies that release games also.   The being said I found the game very fun. The graphics are simple and colourful, the gameplay is mostly relaxed and there is enough content to keep you happy for at least a single playthrough (or a good 10 hours), but don't expect to want to play it again once it's completed. If the game goes on sale then it is worth picking up but don't expect a true tycoon experience where you have an adaptable/changeable economy/market.

While I can respect the concept of the game, the game has one fatal flaw that makes it a chore to play. It doesn't give you at all enough information. What I mean is, when you release a game the feedback from reviews is almost entirely useless drivel like 'Could have been better.' or 'Disappointing.' and even when the reviews do mention specifics it's always vague stuff that you usually already know like 'Fantasy and RPG are a great combination.' Well no ♥♥♥♥ Sherlock. -_- So because the game doesn't give you any useful feedback, game development becomes less a game of design and resource management like it should be and basically just a series of boring trial and error. In summary, the whole time I felt like my games failed for no reason because the game didn't tell me anything about it's seemingly arbitrary formula for dictating good games. This is a fundamental flaw that really ruined the experience for me and made the game feel like a boring chore. I would recommend waiting to play this game until they revise the feedback system.

Game suffers serious game balance issues. One of the most core mechanics is the reviews you earn about your games. Once you set a new high review score every game after it is measured against that in a very lopsided way.  As a single game developer I was able to create 2 simple games that scored near perfect tens. After that, upgrading to a studio and having a team of developers it then becomes impossible to rank in comparison and scores drop from those 10s to 4s thereby damning your hopes of publishing games without losses for not scoring high enough reviews.  I did some research into the game theory of these mechanics and while the game appears to be open and controllable you really have no control. Basically you need to just pick predefined combinations of game genres, systems, and target age groups. There is no dynamic changes in the game, it is just rote memorization. Ultimately it comes down to a giant matrix and either you do exactly as the matrix says or you face extreme penalties.   I can't really recommend this game. If you own mobile devices the Game Dev Story from Kairosoft is superior. While GDS is simpler in some ways it does not suffer the overwhelming core flaw of this game. Also this game itself is basically a direct copy of Kairosoft's work. This game appears to give you more freedom choice compaerd to GDS but your choice is illusionary, there is no choice and must do exactly as the game demands to progress.  I wish steam allowed returns as I would return this game for a refund as I'm disappointed.

The graphics are poor. It looks like a flash game ported to Steam, but that's fine. The game could be text-based and still be fun.  The problem is the graphics are poor  and  they are resource intensive. My game can lag and become unplayable in the late-game stages when the developers are shooting up lots of little progress bubbles to develop a game. My computer isn't a great computer, but it can play Skyrim and GTA IV and other 3D games. It should be able to generate little 2D colored bubbles without freezing.   The concept was great. Come on bro! Calculating scores based on your previous high scores is just not quite right. Got couples 9.75s using current best engines and then the scores dropped to 5s or 4s because there is nothing to upgrade or to improve. Does this mean that I have to INTENTIONALLY produce not-so-good games to get high scores later on? (Please dont doubt me, since on my second play through, I used all stats according to the best-combo charts.)
