Finally, I have to admit that this game is quite addicting at first and is definitely worth it. Probably not 9.99 but a 6.99 or so would be perfect.  Anyway, I think I might just take this game too seriously.

Review: Honestly, I was pretty let down by this game. Played it for a little bit and just decided to let it gather dust in the library. If I could go back in time and not purchase it I would. At least I got it cheap in a sale. Now your probably wondering why this is so. Well here it goes.  For one there is no other companies to compete with but yourself in the game. Yeah it is kind of fun, for like the first hour before you look up how to score high games cause the ratings start to suck, and you find out that the game punishes you for being innovative.   Pros: +Good techtree with alot of things to research and cool things to add to games +Fun graphics  Cons: -Never fully use all the cool techs you get because then it would make your games good and the reviews poor. -Game mechanics punish you for being innovative and making the best games at the time -No other companies other than the ones making the platforms (PC, Consoles, ect.)   The goal of the game is to make games that are slightly, if marginally better the each previous game. If you make to rapid advancements and innovation too quickly than your games wont get more 'points' and you plateau. It becomes very tedious, and for what? A question I cannot answer.  Final Thoughts: Going into this game I thought the point was to be innovative, make the best games you can and beat the compitition. But that is not the case, there is no compitition. The goal is to make crappy games, and games that are slightly less crappy than the last to bank on the system and become the next virtual EA. That's not my cup of tea.  If thats your thing go for it, but for me I was not impressed and this game is more of a novelty item if anything. If your really looking for a game dev simulator than it will scratch that itch for a brief moment and overall is 'lacking'.  4/10 Would not recommend  P.S. I was sold by the overwhelming positive reviews, but shortly realized my mistake. This game is a fun gimmick, but fades pretty fast. If the mechanics where better or there were other companies to compete with, and it was a race to get ahead and build a company that does at least something better than the others like how the big companies of today got going, which was what I expected, then this review would be much higher. But as it stands it was not even close. Perhaps I had my hopes to high, perhaps I was expecting something that 'Game Dev Tycoon' would offer, perhaps I was just foolish thinking a 96% favorable game could not disappoint.

Honestly this game gets a neurtral score but this is not possible to do so negative it is. This game is addictive in a short burst. It is the type of game that the 'dollar per hour' rule applies in that you will spend at least 10 hours on this game and you will enjoy those 10 hours or more. That being said the game is inherently flawed in its design. You are constantly trying to beat your previous score. What amounts from that is there is no one to compete with. There are other companies but only in name only. You do not get to see what they create or even scores they get, only that they may be there in the form of a publishing company. The game feels more like a flash game in dynamics and limits yourself to repetitive asset distribution that leaves no variability. Everything comes down to following a formula, it is the type of game where you could literally follow a step by step manual and there would not be the least bit of a problem. The game mechanics are even limited in that regard it feeels too simplistic but vague. It has many interesting nods to previous gaming consoles and follows how they would fair in the game market during the concurrent time but other than that, they are not versitile at all. I made a game with level 3 3d graphics for the equivelent of the original game boy. It isn't the problem with this not following how the gameboy or other consoles were in reality, it is the problem with little to no restrictions to how these consoles work. They are, again, just a medium for reaching an audience and not a deciding factor in much game design.  overall this game is super enjoyable at first, you will enjoy it for the 10+ hours no problem. Just be careful when you pass that mark as the game's problems become more pertinent

GDT is primarily a game of slider adjustment. If, for example, you wish to produce a game of the Action genre, then during Stage 1 of development you'll wish to set the Engine slider to 100%, the Gameplay slider to 80%, and the Story slider to 0%. Meanwhile, your only competition is yourself, and every time you outperform yourself, you raise the bar. If you don't exceed the standard you've set for yourself, improving every game over the last, then your ratings will suffer, and so will your sales. Critics and customers aren't concerned about whether or not you've produced a good game, or an entertaining game. They're interested in whether or not you've produced a game that was statistically better than your last. You'll find yourself frustrated in no time, getting real cozy to all the GDT strategy guides and spreadsheets that litter the internet.   My first game started out enjoyable. I was fascinated by the nostalgia of the Comadore 64 and Nintendo. I liked giving my games titles and momentarily daydreaming about what each would be like. It didn't take long before I adjusted a games sliders luckily and scored my first big hit. Little did I realize the critics and customers would never be accepting of anything less after that. From that point on it was all frustration, confusion and work, eventually leading to bankrupcy during the PS2 era. The next game, I spent most of my time reading those guides and refering to those spreadsheets I mentioned earlier, strategically planning everything with precision. I even downloaded a series of mods that did such things as display percentages in the sliders, for precision purposes. I left nothing to chance, and yet I again found myself bankrupt during the PS2 era.   Before the third playthrough, I must've spent an hour scouring the internet like an NSA agent reading and rereading Vladamir Putin's autobiography and hacked personal correspondance. Finally, I tried one last time, nearly found myself bankrupt during the PS2 era again, but I won with $4.5 billion in my account. Was it worth it? No. There's a lot of examples of 'the wrong execution of the right idea' here. That bar raising I spoke of earlier being one. GDT is unmercifully, artificially and ridiculously difficult. From what I've read, that seemed to be more true with each update released for GDT. They found any patch of fresh air within the game, capped it off, and left the player suffocating. For example, MMO's have been nerfed to the point that insane, rapid and unending rises in server maintenance will leave you broke in no time flat, expansion packs or not. This is, in essense, a game of gaming the game, never playing the game. It's work, not fun. From what I've read, the game used to be fun, but in it's current and apparently final state, it's not. You'll find no joy here.  Unless you're a masochist: steer clear. Find something to play that'll actually be fun.
